Chapter XIII: On Observance

I. The Definition of Sanctification and Conversion

That which in general is conversion for bringing man unto God, is in particular sanctification for sanctifying him unto God, that all observance may be rendered unto Him.

Ames saith: This sanctification is distinguished from that change of man which is proper unto the calling of man in faith and repentance, for that faith there is not properly considered as a quality, but in relation unto Christ; nor is repentance there regarded as a change of disposition, for so it would signify the same as sanctification; but as a change of purpose and intention of the mind. Here, verily, the real change of qualities and dispositions is regarded.

II. Wherein Sanctification Differs from Justification

Sanctification differeth from justification, albeit it be connected thereunto.

Ames saith: It is called a real change, that it may be distinguished not only from justification, but also from that sanctification which cometh by institution, such as the sanctification of the seventh day; or even by the relation of a sign, such as the sanctification of the elements in the sacraments; or finally by manifestation, as God Himself is said to be sanctified by men, 1 Peter 3:15.

Trelcatius saith: For albeit justification and sanctification agree in the efficient causes (both God’s grace and Christ’s merit), in the instrumental cause, faith—of the former indeed by receiving, of the latter by effecting—and finally in the scope and end, for they tend unto one end, yet that as a cause, this as a way; nevertheless, they differ greatly, both according to substance and according to adjuncts. According to substance, that is, according to all the causes. For the matter of justification is the obedience of Christ; of sanctification, our obedience: that perfect, this imperfect. The form of that is the imputation of Christ’s obedience; of this, the reduction of our mind from impure qualities unto pure. The internal proximate efficient cause of justification is none; but of this, the will of man, the principle of human actions. The end of that is peace of conscience; of this, the public testimony of our reconciliation with God. According to adjuncts, they differ: first, in the manner of effecting; that is effected by the right of donation, this by the manner of alteration. Second, in the effects; that absolveth us in the judgment of God, this doth not. Third, in duration; that will have an end with this life; this will endure forever.

Calvin saith: For since faith embraceth Christ as He is offered unto us by the Father, and He is offered not only for righteousness, remission of sins, and peace, but also for sanctification and the fountain of living water, doubtless no one can duly know Him without at the same time apprehending the sanctification of the Spirit. Or if any desire it to be said more plainly, faith consisteth in the knowledge of Christ; Christ cannot be known without the sanctification of His Spirit. It followeth that faith can in no wise be separated from a pious disposition.

III. The Nature of Sanctification

Sanctification is the internal, real, and entire change of man through the Spirit of God, whereby the old man and the dominion of sin are put off, and the new habit of a holier life, or the image of God in Christ, is put on.

Ames saith: Sanctification is the real change of man from the filthiness of sin into the purity of the image of God, Ephesians 4:22-24,“That ye put off concerning the former conversation the old man, which is corrupt according to the deceitful lusts; and be renewed in the spirit of your mind; and that ye put on the new man, which after God is created in righteousness and true holiness.” For as through justification the faithful is properly freed from the guilt of sin, and hath life adjudged unto him, the title of which life is as it were determined in adoption, so by sanctification the same faithful is freed from the filthiness and stain of sin, and the purity of the image of God is restored unto him. It is of the whole man, not of one part only, 1 Thessalonians 5:23, “And the very God of peace sanctify you wholly; and I pray God your whole spirit and soul and body be preserved blameless unto the coming of our Lord Jesus Christ.” Albeit the whole man, or all that is in man, is not immediately changed. And albeit the whole man is partaker of this grace, yet primarily and chiefly it belongeth unto the soul, and afterward from the soul is derived unto the body, insofar as the body itself is capable through that obediential power by which, together with the soul, it is subjected unto the will of God. It is the change of man from sin, that it may be distinguished from that sanctification which is from a merely negative contrary, such as that which is attributed unto the human nature of Christ, which is said to be sanctified or made holy, albeit it was never defiled with sin, while it was the nature of Christ. The term from which is the filthiness, corruption, or stain of sin, 2 Corinthians 7:1, “Having therefore these promises, dearly beloved, let us cleanse ourselves from all filthiness of the flesh and spirit, perfecting holiness in the fear of God.” The term unto which is the purity of the image of God, which is said to be created or recreated in knowledge, righteousness, and holiness, Ephesians 4:24, or conformity unto the law of God, James 1:25,newness of life, Romans 6:4, a new creature, 2 Corinthians 5:17; Galatians 6:15, and the divine nature, 2 Peter 1:4. It is called a new and divine creature:

  1. Because it is not produced from those principles which are in us by nature, as the habits of all arts are produced, which are acquired by industry and discipline, but from a new principle of life communicated unto us by God in calling.
  2. Because it is of a wholly different kind than was our former natural disposition.
  3. Because it representeth, according unto its measure, that highest perfection which is found in God.

Professor saith: This essential perfection consisteth, first, in that all the faculties of the human soul are renewed: the intellect, the will, and the affections, according unto all the precepts of God; then, that they are renewed unto such a degree that sin doth not reign in them, Romans 6:14, and that they walk not according unto the flesh, but according unto the Spirit, Romans 8:1.

IV. The Nature of Repentance

From hence ariseth the repentance of man.

Junius saith: Repentance is a certain change of the mind and soul from evil unto good, proceeding from godly sorrow.

Walaeus saith: God alone regenerateth man; man alone repenteth: God converteth man, and man converteth himself, as Jeremiah speaketh, chapter 31:18, “Turn Thou me, and I shall be turned; for Thou art the LORD my God. Surely after that I was turned, I repented; and after that I was instructed, I smote upon my thigh.” And the bride, Song of Solomon 1:4, “Draw me, we will run after Thee.” John 6:44, “No man can come unto Me, except the Father which hath sent Me draw him.” Psalm 51:17, “The sacrifices of God are a broken spirit: a broken and a contrite heart, O God, Thou wilt not despise.” From which places it appeareth that the action of God converting man and of man repenting are always conjoined: and the first in man is effected by God or by the grace of God; the other is effected by man, moved by the grace of God. “The grace of God that was with me,” saith the Apostle, 1 Corinthians 15:10, “labored more abundantly than they all: yet not I, but the grace of God which was with me.” Therefore, passively in the first moment of conversion, man comporteth himself, insofar as he receiveth those powers: not only passively, but also actively, when he exerciseth the powers received in the same moment. As the man unto whom Christ restored sight saw in the same moment: and Lazarus, having obtained life, and being admonished by the word, arose in the same moment.

V. Repentance Includeth and Presupposeth Penitence

Repentance includeth and presupposeth penitence, which is true and godly sorrow for sins, and sincere detestation thereof.

Luther saith: The Lord and Master Jesus Christ, saying, “Repent ye,” etc., willed that the whole life of the faithful should be repentance.

Witsius saith: It is manifest that the word repentance is derived from punishment: for as Aulus Gellius rightly noteth, those things which are for shame and disgrace have the force of punishing. Therefore, since he who is led by true repentance for some deed exacteth from himself, within himself, almost the punishment of the same, therefore this affection of the mind hath received the name of repentance: whence also the Apostle himself, 2 Corinthians 7:11, enumerateth among the true properties of repentance indignation and revenge, which the sinner taketh upon himself through that internal sorrow which is wont to accompany misdeeds.

VI. Faith Precedeth Repentance in Nature

Faith precedeth repentance in nature, both taken for a special virtue, and in their proper acts, insofar as that respecteth justification; this, holiness of life: but repentance considered more generally, for the whole change and conversion of man, and with the completed act of faith, precedeth faith in the order of nature.

Professor saith: From what hath hitherto been said, the solution to a sufficiently difficult question appeareth, in the explanation whereof some great authors of the Reformed Church seem to disagree: whether faith be a part of repentance? For if the word repentance be taken in a broad signification, for the whole work of our conversion, as it is sometimes used in Scripture, Acts 3:19; 11:18, certainly our faith is also in it, just as unbelief contrary thereto is comprehended under the unrepentant heart by the Apostle, Romans 2:5. But if the word repentance be taken strictly, as it was defined by us before, then it is wont to be distinguished from faith, as a cause and its proper effect and fruit. And so Scripture itself distinguisheth it in diverse places. See Mark 1:15; Acts 20:21. For that we may truly hate sin, seriously grieve for God offended, as a benign father, love righteousness, and conceive hope of pardon, and spiritual joy of mind from it, it is altogether necessary that we first apply Christ unto ourselves through faith, and behold God in Him as a benign father, although we also freely confess that that saving sense of faith exerteth and confirmeth itself more and more in us through the consent of true repentance.

Voetius saith: Problem: Whether faith precede regeneration, or at least repentance? Response: The former negatively, the latter affirmatively concerning faith in the first act, which in the order of nature precedeth repentance, both in the first act and in the second act considered. But negatively concerning faith in the second act, at least completed or formed. For such faith is necessarily preceded in the order of nature and time by some acts of repentance.

VII. The Parts of Repentance

The parts of repentance are the mortification of the old man and the vivification of the new.

Trelcatius saith: The integral parts hereof are two, according unto the two terms from which it is and unto which this change tendeth: the mortification of the old man or flesh, and the vivification of the new man or spirit, for by these true repentance is perfected. Mortification, which is the first part of repentance, hath three properties or degrees: the acknowledgment of sin, sorrow for sin and for God offended, and finally the detestation and flight from sin. Acknowledgment is in the mind, sorrow in the passion, flight in the action of the will. Vivification, which is the latter, compriseth three things contrary unto mortification: the acknowledgment and confidence of God’s mercy in Christ, the joy arising therefrom, and finally an ardent zeal for holiness, righteousness, and new obedience throughout life, Romans 6:4-5; Ephesians 4:22; Colossians 3:5-6; Psalm 34:15; Isaiah 1:16-17.

Maccovius saith: The parts of regeneration are two: mortification and vivification, Ephesians 4:22-23; Colossians 3:1,5,8-10. The mortification of the old man is that by which the power of sin is gradually weakened and destroyed, Romans 6:2-5; Galatians 5:24. The old man is the whole unregenerate man, as he is, within and without, subject unto sin. Nor doth it oppose this that it is called flesh, John 3:6,since by the word flesh is understood not that fleshy mass of the body, but the vicious and unregenerate nature of the whole man, both soul and body. For (to omit other things) phronēma is attributed unto the flesh, which belongeth not unto the body alone without the soul. The remedy of mortification is the death and burial of Christ, from which proceedeth the power that taketh away the power of sin to rage, and as it were maketh it die and rot in the grave, Romans 6:5. Vivification of the new man is that by which inherent and inchoate holiness is perpetually and gradually increased, Ephesians 2:1; 4:22-24. The new man is the regenerated nature of man, which is renewed after the image of God. And albeit it is called spirit, John 6:63, yet it is not to be understood of the soul only, since the whole man is understood to be spiritual, who is therefore called spirit, that his nature may be signified as perennial, pure, and immortal. The remedy of vivification is the virtue emanating from the resurrection of Christ, and making us rise in newness of life, Philippians 3:10.

VIII. True Mortification Includeth Self-Denial

In true mortification is contained the denial of oneself.

Ames saith: From this mortification followeth in all the sanctified the denial of themselves and of the world, Luke 9:23; Galatians 6:14.

IX. The Distinctions of Repentance

Repentance is either universal or particular; initial or continued; ordinary or extraordinary; private or public.

Walaeus saith: This true and evangelical repentance is divided into universal, when namely a man first passeth from the state of sin into righteousness, and initially turneth unto God, and particular, when a man already converted and faithful, prevented by sin, grieveth for it, and repenteth thereof. This particular is again double, either ordinary or extraordinary. Ordinary is that which truly faithful and holy men are bound to exercise throughout the course of life, from the consciousness of infirmity and daily lapses, Romans 7:24. Extraordinary is when the faithful fall into some grave sin, deeply wounding the conscience; such as we see in David and Peter after their falls. Which again is either of one of the faithful or of the whole assembly and Church; since many examples of this repentance occur in the Scriptures, proposed for mitigating or preventing the wrath of God. And this extraordinary repentance, whether public or private, was always conjoined with extraordinary signs of sorrow and humiliation, such as fastings, weepings, sackcloth, rending of garments.

Question: But it is asked whether one who relapseth into the same vice or scandal ought to be admitted unto second repentance in the Church?

Response: There is no example of any saint in the whole Scripture. For Aaron and Miriam sinned once: Lot, David, Peter, etc., fell once into the same sin and scandal: and therefore this cannot be proven by examples. Yet Lot fell twice into incest, and into drunkenness: David into diverse vices, as into adultery, and afterward into murder, unless these followed each other mutually, as the triple denial of Peter: but these acts were almost conjoined. But nevertheless, the promises are general, and the invitations unto repentance, even second and third. As Ezekiel 18:23, “Have I any pleasure at all that the wicked should die? saith the Lord GOD: and not that he should return from his ways, and live?” And 33:16, “If the wicked restore the pledge, etc., none of his sins that he hath committed shall be mentioned unto him.” They are called back unto repentance who had been converted before and had relapsed into the same vices, Galatians 4:19, “My little children, of whom I travail in birth again until Christ be formed in you.” Luke 17:4; Matthew 18:21, we are commanded to forgive a brother seven times, yea, seventy times seven.

X. The Effect of Sanctification and the End of Repentance

The effect of sanctification and that unto which repentance tendeth is the observance of divine precepts.

Ames saith: Observance is that by which the will of God is rendered with subjection unto His glory. It respecteth the will of God as the exemplar and rule, as appeareth from those words of Christ, by which He both describeth our observance (“Thy will be done in earth, as it is in heaven”) and explained His own, Matthew 26:39, “Not as I will, but as Thou wilt.” And verse 42, “Thy will be done.” So Psalm 40:8,“I delight to do Thy will, O my God: yea, Thy law is within my heart.” But it respecteth the will of God, not that which is secret and powerfully effecting or ordering: for so all other creatures, and wicked men, and even the devils themselves, fulfill the will of God by that obediential virtue which is common unto all creatures: but it respecteth that will of God which prescribeth our duty unto us, Deuteronomy 29:29, “The secret things belong unto the LORD our God: but those things which are revealed belong unto us and unto our children forever, that we may do all the words of this law.” It respecteth that will with subjection, Romans 8:7, because it applieth our will unto fulfilling the will of God, by which He commandeth something unto us for His authority, Romans 8:7, “Because the carnal mind is enmity against God: for it is not subject unto the law of God, neither indeed can be.” Hence it is called obedience because it rendereth the will prompt to commit unto execution the command of God heard or in any wise perceived. Hence also it hath in itself some reason of servitude toward God: whence it is that to obey God and to serve Him sound as one and the same, Luke 1:74; Romans 6:16, and to serve God is plainly the same as to serve obedience and righteousness, verses 16, 18, 22, because to do the will of God with subjection is to serve God, Ephesians 6:6-7, “As the servants of Christ, doing the will of God from the heart; with good will doing service, as unto the Lord.” For our obedience toward God, albeit with respect unto the promptitude of the mind it ought to be the obedience of sons, yet with respect unto the strict obligation unto subjection, it is the obedience of servants.

XI. The Nature of Good Works

Good works are those which are performed by the regenerate through the grace of the Holy Spirit and from faith, according unto the law of God, unto His glory, and unto the salvation of ourselves and our neighbor.

Zanchius saith: By the name of good works, we understand all those actions and works which are done by the regenerate, according unto the prescription of the divine will revealed in the Word, and from living faith in Christ, and thus from a pure heart, through the Holy Spirit, 1 Peter 1:5; 1 Timothy 1:5. For as everything that is not of faith is sin, Romans 14:23, so all things which are done from faith, and thus from a pure heart and a good conscience, must needs be good works. Wherefore, we think that those things which are done by the wicked without faith, without the Word of God, and without the guidance of the Holy Spirit, cannot by any means be numbered among good works and those pleasing unto God, however much they may have the appearance of the greatest piety and divine worship, Colossians 2:18,23; Matthew 15:8-9.

Trelcatius saith: The doctrine of good works must be explained in two ways. First, according unto their common nature and reason; second, according unto the principal species of the Christian life and the primary exercises of the Christian man in this life. Good works according unto their common nature and reason, which indeed are considered by us theologically, not philosophically or politically in this place, are defined as actions which, by the operation of the Holy Spirit, are done by the regenerate through faith, according unto the law of God, unto the glory of God, unto the confirmation of our faith and election, and unto the edification of our neighbor.

Ames saith: For such an action, there is required, first, a good efficient or principle, that is, a will well-disposed and acting from true virtue; for good fruits are born only from a good tree, Matthew 12:33. Second, a good matter or object, that is, something commanded by God, Matthew 15:9. Third, a good end, that is, the glory of God, and those things which tend unto His glory, 1 Corinthians 10:31,“Whether therefore ye eat, or drink, or whatsoever ye do, do all unto the glory of God.” But the end and the object often coincide in both good and evil actions, especially in the intention and choice of the will, where the end itself is the proper object. For those acts are either in the end itself, as in the matter or object, such as the acts of desiring, willing, wishing, loving, enjoying; or in those things which tend unto the end, as such, so that the goodness or deformity is properly derived from the end.

Maccovius saith: Good works are those which are done from true faith, Hebrews 11:6; Romans 14:23, according unto the law of God, Deuteronomy 12:8; 28:38; Numbers 15:39; Isaiah 29:13; Matthew 15:7-8, and are referred unto His glory alone, 1 Corinthians 10:32; Colossians 3:17. Therefore, if one of these three conditions be lacking in our works, they will by no means be good works.

Professor saith: The ends of good works are three: of which the first respecteth us, namely, the testimony of our gratitude toward God, by which at the same time our election and calling are confirmed in us, Romans 12:1-2; 1 Corinthians 6:19-20; 2 Peter 2:5,9-10. For from good works, as from sacrifices acceptable unto God, and from the indubitable marks of justifying faith, we are made more certain of our election and thus of our calling unto salvation, as is clear from this admonition of Peter, 2 Peter 1:10, “Wherefore the rather, brethren, give diligence to make your calling and election sure: for if ye do these things, ye shall never fall.” And also from the promise of Christ, John 15:8, by which He promiseth that the hearers of the Gospel will certainly know from the fruits of good works that they are His true disciples and branches truly grafted into Him forever. The second end is the edification of our neighbor, whether he be faithful or unfaithful. For when by doing good, we go before others aptōsēpoi, that is, without offense, and openly show the sincerity of our faith, then the faithful is confirmed in the same faith with us; but the unfaithful is either allured unto it or put to shame, if he nevertheless attacketh our good conversation in Christ, 1 Corinthians 10:32, as Lactantius elegantly gathereth, Book 5, Institutes, Chapter 9, “When the unfaithful see,” he saith, “both themselves and their own doing those things which we have said, but ours doing nothing else but what is just and good, they could, if they had any sense, understand from this that those who do good are pious, and they themselves are impious who commit nefarious things, for it cannot be that those who do not err in all the actions of their life should err in the chief thing, that is, in religion, which is the head of all things.” The third and ultimate end, unto which the two preceding are subordinated, is the glory of God. For the regenerate are constituted in this world, and in the midst of a perverse nation, by God, not only that they themselves may glorify God irreprehensibly and sincerely, both in works and in word, but also that, as lights, they may provoke all others by their good works unto glorifying God, Matthew 5:16; Philippians 2:15; John 15:8. And thus the end, conjoined with the preceding by an indivisible nexus, followeth good works in its order with them, and therefore is called by a common name with them, now their fruit, now their use, now their effect.

Ames saith: Unto a good example is opposed scandal, 1 Corinthians 10:32-33, “Give none offense, neither unto the Jews, nor unto the Gentiles, nor unto the church of God.” Scandal is the representation of an evil work, by which others may either be excited unto sin (whence it is called skandalon, or a cause of stumbling) or be hindered or retarded from doing good (whence it is called astheneia, or a cause of weakness), and properly scandal is called, 1 Corinthians 8:9, “But take heed lest by any means this liberty of yours become a stumblingblock unto them that are weak.” Romans 14:21, “In which thy brother stumbleth, or is offended, or is made weak.” In every evil work that becometh known unto others, there is the reason of scandal, Matthew 18:6-8. It is also sometimes in a work lawful in itself, if by reason of others it be not expedient, 1 Corinthians 8:13, “Wherefore, if meat make my brother to offend, I will eat no flesh while the world standeth, lest I make my brother to offend.” But if offense followeth not from the condition of our work, but from the pure malice of others, then it is called scandal received, as that of the Pharisees, which is not our sin, but theirs who are offended, Matthew 15:12-14. Albeit this scandal received cannot be avoided by us, yet that given can and ought to be. For God never imposeth on His own the necessity of offending anyone.

Bucanus saith: Scandal is threefold: active, or given, or posited; passive, or received; and mixed from both.

XII. The Works of the Gentiles Are Not Truly Good

From this, it is clear that the works of the Gentiles were not truly and rightly good.

Professor saith: Unto that definition of good works abundantly explained, if the moral and civil virtues of the Gentiles be examined, they cannot and ought not to be praised by us as good before God, since no part of that definition agreeth with them. For neither do their virtues proceed from the Spirit of regeneration, since they are carnal, nor from justifying faith, without which it is impossible to please God, since they either ignore or repudiate the righteousness of Christ; nor from true charity, since this is the hand of faith by which it acteth, which God demandeth by His law: nor are they done by them for God, who is the universal end, and conjoined with the eternal salvation of the workers; but for some particular end, which terminateth with their life in this age: namely, either for gain, or for popular favor, or for civil honors to be procured for themselves. Yet the virtues of the unfaithful are not absolutely or in themselves evil, but relatively and accidentally. For they are good materially, and considered nakedly; they are evil radically and formally. Radically, insofar as they emanate from an evil and impure heart: formally, insofar as they are done otherwise than they ought. Therefore, Cyprian calleth the virtues of the unfaithful Gentiles false virtues. Jerome, vicious. Augustine, looking unto the statement of Paul, Romans 14:23, saith: “However much the works of the unfaithful are praised, we know the sentence of the Apostle to be true, that everything which is not of faith, namely, from the command of God, and leaning on the righteousness of Christ, is sin. If a Gentile clotheth the naked, is it sin because it is not of faith? Altogether, insofar as it is not of faith, it is sin; not because the deed itself, which is to clothe the naked, is sin, but not to glory in the Lord in such a work, only the impious denieth it to be sin.” Cyprian, Book 1, De Bono Patientiae; Jerome, Chapter 3, Ad Galatas; Augustine, De Gestis Palestinis, Chapter 14, and Contra Julianum, Book 4, Chapter 3.

XIII. The Works of the Romanists Are Not Good

And also it is clear that the works of the Romanists, who under the pretext of good intention evilly palliate their own, are not good.

Maccovius saith: And from this definition, it is clear that the Romanists act badly, who, under the pretext of good intention and the appearance of piety, depart from the norm of good works proposed unto us in the Word of God, as if they would do more or better things than God Himself hath prescribed. But God commandeth that we walk not in the statutes of our fathers, Ezekiel 20:18-19.

Professor saith: From the number of good works are deservedly excluded those which are done according unto the traditions of the Romanists from a good intention, and by voluntary worship, albeit they have some reason of wisdom and submission of mind, and are adorned with the splendid title of Apostolic and Ecclesiastical institution, Isaiah 29:13; Matthew 15:9; Colossians 2:22-23. Of which kind are monastic vows and fastings, the worship of saints, pilgrimages unto their monuments, and the like, which have no kinship with the works of piety.

XIV. The Form of Good Works

The form of good works is a just conformity with the law of God.

Trelcatius saith: The form of good works is full and perfect conformity in all its parts with the law of God, both according unto the external appearance and according unto the internal truth, Deuteronomy 27:26; Galatians 3:10; Romans 7:14. For two things concur unto the constitution of this form: the external goodness of works, which the precepts of the law externally bear and require, and the internal holiness of the same, which the nature of the law, which is spiritual, and of the lawgiver, who is a spirit and a searcher of hearts, according unto His manner, necessarily presupposeth and demandeth.

Ames saith: The form of observance is our conformity unto the will of God, revealed for this very reason, that it may be fulfilled by us, Micah 6:8, “He hath shewed thee, O man, what is good.” For neither is the secret will of God the norm of our observance, nor all that is revealed (for Jeroboam sinned in occupying the kingdom of Israel, albeit God had in some wise indicated unto him that He willed it, 1 Kings 11:31, with 2 Chronicles 13:5-7), but that which, prescribing our duty, is revealed for this reason, that it may be fulfilled by us. But this will of God, by this very reason, is called good, perfect, and acceptable unto God, Romans 12:2, good, because it embraceth in itself every reason of honesty: perfect, because nothing further is to be sought for the institution of life: acceptable unto God, because the obedience rendered unto this will is approved and crowned by God.

XV. The Necessity of Good Works

Good works are necessary for religion and salvation.

Professor saith: Necessity is attributed unto good works in many ways. For they are called necessary:

  1. By the necessity of divine precept.
  2. By the necessity of means, ordained unto the glory of God and our salvation.
  3. By the necessity of worship and obedience, due unto God from our natural obligation.
  4. By the necessity of a good and tranquil conscience, well conscious of its own election and calling unto salvation.
  5. By the necessity of the duty of charity to be rendered unto our neighbor.

XVI. Of True Virtue

In that conformity of our action with the law of God lieth virtue.

Ames saith: The parts of observance are two: virtue and the action of virtue, 2 Peter 1:5,8, “And beside this, giving all diligence, add unto your faith virtue; and unto virtue knowledge, etc. For if these things be in you, and abound, they make you that ye shall neither be barren nor unfruitful in the knowledge of our Lord Jesus Christ.” This distribution is of the whole into its members. For by their nature, these two are conjoined, and constitute one and the same observance. Hence, by the same name, both virtues and their actions are denoted, and are explained by the same definition, because they are of the same nature, just as logical arguments are of the same name and nature, whether considered alone and by themselves, or in axioms and syllogisms. Virtue is a habit by which the will is inclined unto doing well. The action of virtue is either internal or external, 2 Corinthians 8:10-11, “And herein I give my advice: for this is expedient for you, who have begun before, not only to do, but also to be forward a year ago. Now therefore perform the doing of it.” The internal action is properly of the will itself. The external action is of another faculty distinct from the will; whether it be of the intellect, or of the sensitive appetite, which is commonly called internal, or of the executive power, which is usually called external. The internal action of the will hath goodness or depravity so intrinsic that the same act cannot remain in the genus of nature without being the same also in the genus of morals; but the external act can remain the same in the genus of nature and yet become another in the genus of morals, from good, namely, unto evil, or from evil unto good; as if one beginning to walk from an honest purpose persisteth in the journey for an evil end. The internal acts and the external acts commanded by it have one and the same goodness or depravity; for it is the same act in the genus of morals. For to will to worship God and from that will to worship God are not two acts of obedience, but two degrees of one and the same act, so that the goodness of the one is perfected in the other, 2 Corinthians 8:11, “Now therefore perform the doing of it.”

XVII. Of the Merit of Good Works

But there is no merit in any of our actions, however good.

Professor saith: The dignity of good works is not to be estimated from their merit, as the Romanists will, but from the grace of God alone, as the Gospel teacheth. For if God examined them according unto the rigor of His law, they would be worthy of censure rather than of His favor and benefit because of their imperfection; which God, however, for the sake of Christ His beloved Son, who covereth all our infirmities with His perfect righteousness, and offereth our works as fruits of the Spirit working in us through faith in His own name, deigneth to accept from the throne of His paternal grace and to crown with eternal glory. Besides that, it clearly appeareth from their imperfection that our works can merit nothing before God from their internal dignity; the same can be proven by the following reasons, of which the first is that those works have no proportion of equality unto the promised reward of future life, since they are finite and temporal, but that is infinite and eternal. Wherefore, the Apostle Paul asserteth that the momentary sufferings of the saints for the name of Christ are infinitely outweighed by the remuneration of heavenly glory, Romans 8:18. The same must be affirmed much more concerning the promised remuneration for our actions, which are to be done less than the sufferings of the holy martyrs; and so far is it that from this saying of the Apostle the distinction of the Romanists between merit of congruity and merit of condignity can be rightly drawn, that nothing is more suitable to overthrow it. For if between works and the reward of the heavenly kingdom there is no analogy of equality, neither doth that have the reason of merit, nor this of compensation to be attributed from the equitable estimation of justice. The second reason is that good works, insofar as they are good, proceed from the Holy Spirit, and therefore are not properly our works, but gratuitous gifts of God, which are accepted by Him when brought forth by us, because we have them not from ourselves but from Him, and offer them unto Him as organs of His Spirit, as Augustine rightly observed, Homily 39, De Tempore. The third reason is that our works are due, which God, as the supreme and only Lord, unto whom we and all ours are due, justly demandeth from us; if our works are due unto God as our Lord, certainly we can merit nothing before God by them, and on the contrary, if they are meritorious, they are not due unto Him by right of dominion. But that they are due unto God by right of dominion, Christ showeth by the similitude taken from a servant, Luke 17:9-10. The fourth reason is that by our works we bestow nothing on the Lord God that so preventeth His kindness that anything accrueth unto Him, by whose benefit He deemeth Himself bound unto us. Which reason is conjoined by Christ with the preceding, Luke 17:10, when He saith that in this respect we are unprofitable servants unto God: and the same is set before our eyes, Job 35:7, “If thou be righteous, what givest thou Him? or what receiveth He of thine hand?” And 41:11, “Who hath prevented Me, that I should repay him? Whatsoever is under the whole heaven is Mine.” Romans 11:35, unto which may be added that the very word “merit” is new, as is the meritorious doctrine, and was never used by the theopneustoi, the inspired writers of God. Albeit Ecclesiasticus is not of their number, and therefore not an autoptes witness among us, yet we will note that the word used by him, chapter 16:14, namely, erga, denoteth works, not merits, as the Romanists think, who prefer to follow the perverse version of the Latin interpreter rather than to embrace the genuine interpretation of the original text shown by us, as also appeareth from the place in Hebrews 13:16, from which, that they may build up their merit of condignity, they prefer to expound the word eucharistein with the old interpreter by the word “promeretur” rather than with us by the word “to delight,” albeit no one skilled in the Greek language and at the same time orthodox will deny that this rather than that expresseth the mind of the Apostle. No less absurdly is the word “reward,” which is very often found in the sacred letters, brought to establish the same merit, since the salvation of souls or eternal life is never promised in the Gospel unto our works as a due reward, but as an undue and gratuitous remuneration, and therefore is now called the end of faith, as in 1 Peter 1:9, now the gift of God, as in Romans 6:23, now finally an inheritance, reserved for us in heaven as co-heirs with Christ by the grace of adoption, as in 1 Peter 1:4. Moses looked unto that remuneration with the eyes of faith, by which, relying on the reproach of Christ, which is expiatory, according unto the gratuitous promise made unto Abraham and his seed, he esteemed the reproach of Christ greater riches than the treasures of Egypt, Hebrews 11:26. We also, wandering in this rough desert, may look unto the same remuneration, provided that we expect it not as a stipend, after the manner of hirelings, but as an inheritance to be gratuitously assigned unto us, as it becometh servants adopted as sons, from our Lord and heavenly Father, and with the sweet solace of this expectation, we may dilute the troubles of the present life. The orthodox fathers, using the words “merit” and “to merit”:

  1. Take the word “merit” in both parts, for a good or evil work, as is seen in Augustine, Epistle 46, where he distinguisheth the evil merit of the impious from the good merit of the pious.
  2. They take the word “to merit” for to obtain or to attain, as in the Acts of the Council of Carthage, cognition of article 258, “That we may omit how much Christian blood was shed through Leontius, Ursatius, Macarius, and other executors whom they merited from the princes of the world for the slaughter of the saints.” And in the first Sunday of the Lord’s advent, “Stir up, we beseech Thee, Thy power, and come, that from the imminent dangers of our sins we may merit to be delivered by Thy protection, and to be saved by Thy bounty.”
  3. Lest anyone from the abuse of those words should assign an internal meritorious dignity unto good works, they sometimes affirm that they are worthy rather of God’s commiseration than of the compensation of eternal life. See Augustine on Psalm 49:61; Bernard, Sermon 67 on the Canticles. Wherefore, the Romanists are worthy of severer censure, because they are not ashamed to elicit their dogma of the merits of good works not only from the sayings of Sacred Scripture but also from those of the ancient fathers perversely distorted. We, bidding them farewell, conclude with Bernard from the preceding arguments that the mercy of God is our merit.

XVIII. The Matter of Good Works and Virtue

The matter of good works and virtue is contained in the two tables of the law: of which the first comprehendeth four precepts, the second six.

Trelcatius saith: The matter of good works is whatsoever is prescribed by the law of God. For God alone hath the authority of commanding, and the law of God alone hath the norm and reason of every precept that regardeth what is just and good. Of this matter, according unto the distinction of the divine law into two tables, there are two principal and primary parts, of which the first prescribeth the duty of man toward God or piety, the latter the duty of man toward man, or humanity, and commandeth it. Those good works which regard piety are absolutely and necessarily good, and cannot be otherwise: the reason whereof is most perfectly circumscribed by the four precepts of the first table. For the works of piety either regard properly the internal disposition of the mind, as, namely, that we hold the truth and worship of the true God (which is by the first precept) and the manner of that truth (which is explained by the second): or they regard the external testimony of the body, as, namely, that we apply ourselves unto all exercises of piety both with the mouth (which is by the third) and with work (which is by the fourth precept). Those good works which regard humanity are most perfectly explained by the six precepts of the second table. For first, the foundation of them all is placed in the fifth precept, that mutual obedience and relation of duty of inferiors toward superiors, and of superiors toward inferiors; then the principal species of humanity are enumerated, unto which all the rest must necessarily be referred analogically. The sum of these is not to harm our neighbor, neither in deed, nor in word, nor in thought. Not in deed, without respect unto his person (thou shalt not kill), or with respect unto his goods (thou shalt not steal), or with respect unto the person who most closely toucheth him (thou shalt not commit adultery). Not in word: for no false testimony is to be spoken against him. Not finally in mind and thought: for even concupiscence itself is forbidden.

Calvin saith: Nor is it ill to direct our study unto knowing the division of the precepts: provided thou remember that it is of that kind in which each one’s judgment ought to be free, for which reason one should not contentiously fight with one who dissenteth. For indeed, this place must necessarily be touched by us, lest the readers should either laugh at or wonder at the division which we are about to posit, as if it were new and recently devised. That the law is distinguished into ten words, because it is often confirmed by the authority of God Himself, is beyond controversy. Wherefore, there is no dispute about the number, but about the manner of dividing. Those who so divide it that they give three precepts unto the first table and reject the remaining seven into the second, expunge the precept concerning images from the number, or at least hide it under the first: when it is undoubtedly placed by the Lord distinctly in the place of a command; but the tenth, concerning not coveting the things of our neighbor, they ineptly cut into two. Moreover, that such a manner of dividing was unknown in a purer age will soon be understood. Others number with us four heads in the first table: but instead of the first, they establish a promise without a precept. But I, because, unless I am convinced by evident reason, I take the ten words in Moses for ten precepts, and I seem unto myself to see as many most beautifully arranged in order: with their opinion permitted, I will follow what is more approved by me, namely, that what they make the first precept should hold the place of a preface unto the whole law: then follow four precepts of the first table, six of the second table, in the order in which they will be recited. This division Origen handed down without controversy, as if it were everywhere received in his age. Augustine also agreeth in his letter unto Boniface, who observeth this order in enumeration.

XIX. The Authority of the Moral Law

The force and authority of the moral law pertain also unto Christians and unto all men.

Zuinglius saith: We are not so freed from the law that we ought not to do what the law willeth: for the law of God is the immutable will. For not one jot shall fall from the law, Luke 16:17.

Professor saith: That this law pertaineth no less unto Christians under the New Testament than unto the Jews under the Old, we prove by these arguments:

  1. That it is the external image of the internal law of nature impressed on our first parents before the fall, through their creation after the image of God, which is placed in holiness and righteousness, the duties of which virtues the Decalogue representeth unto all men, and the Gospel demandeth from the household of faith renewed after the image of God by the Spirit of God.
  2. That this law, revealed unto our first parents, repeated and restored through Moses, was expounded not only by the Prophets but also by Christ and the Apostles, observed by them, and strictly commended unto others, Matthew 5:17ff.; Luke 10:27; Romans 6:13; 7:25; 12; 13.
  3. Because the sons of God are described by the observation of the commands of this law, as by a tekmērion, and an infallible testimony of true conjunction with God, 1 John 1:6-7; 2:3-6.
  4. Because charity from unfeigned faith and a good conscience (which is the end of the Decalogue) is set before Timothy as a scope unto which he ought to refer all his actions, 1 Timothy 1:5.

Geneva saith: That the moral law, as far as it concerneth the saints, that is, the believers, was indeed abolished by the coming of Christ, but only as to damnation: and that because Christ was made a curse for them. For in the elect, it still retaineth a double use, namely, that it may restrain the old man, whose remnants still survive in them, by the fear of punishments: but may instruct the new man created in them in the ways of the Lord: but as far as it concerneth the impenitent, it hath retained and will retain until the end of the ages that first use in convicting and condemning them without mercy: but as to the other two saving uses, it is utterly useless unto them by their own fault. Therefore, the Libertines, Antinomians, and others who repudiate the moral law are to be execrated.

XX. The Exposition of the Law

The exposition of the law must always be taken in its greatest latitude.

Ursinus saith: Therefore, that each of the precepts of the Decalogue may be rightly understood, at the beginning some general rules for their exposition are to be held: of which the first is: The Decalogue is to be understood according unto the declaration handed down through Moses, the Prophets, Christ, and the Apostles. The second, the law of God requireth entire obedience, internal and external, in the mind, will, heart, and actions, that is, in words, deeds, and external gestures. The third, the obedience of all other precepts is to be referred unto the first precept. For in it, the love and celebration of the only true God above all things in all actions and in the whole life of man is commanded. Therefore, unless the love of God and the thought of the divine will be the impulsive cause, and the zeal to affect the true God with honor through our obedience be the final cause of all other works, neither are they done according unto the sense of the law, nor can they be the worship of God and please God. The fourth, the sense of each law is to be taken from the end for which it was enacted. For then the law is rightly understood when it is referred and extended unto those things which the lawgiver willed to be obtained and attained through it. But when one goeth beyond them or stoppeth short of them, one erreth from the mind of the lawgiver. The fifth, for diverse ends, one and the same work can be commanded or contained in diverse precepts: because ends make the distinctions of actions; as defense, insofar as it is the duty of parents toward children, or of magistrates toward subjects, is commanded in the fifth precept: insofar as it is the duty of fortitude preserving the life of the neighbor, it is contained in the sixth precept. The sixth, affirmative or imperative precepts include negative or prohibitive, and conversely. For what is commanded, its contrary is prohibited: and what is prohibited, its contrary is commanded. But contraries are understood not only of omissions to deeds, but also of deeds to deeds. When theft and murder are prohibited, not only the omission of them is commanded, but also the zeal to protect the goods and life of the neighbor. The seventh, when some principal species is commanded or prohibited, also the cognate species or the whole genus is commanded or prohibited. For like things are to be judged alike in that in which they are alike. But species of virtues or vices are commanded or prohibited because of the end in which they agree with the cognates. Therefore, since the cause of the command or prohibition is found the same in the rest, the command and prohibition ought to be extended unto them. The eighth, where the effect is commanded or prohibited, there also the cause is understood to be commanded or prohibited. For he who willeth something to be done also requireth those things without which this cannot be done; and he who prohibiteth something also willeth those things to be avoided without which this cannot be guarded against. When honor and obedience toward superiors are commanded, modesty is also commanded. For he doth not prefer others unto himself whom he acknowledgeth as superior. When chastity is commanded and lusts are prohibited, at the same time temperance, the nurse of chastity, is necessarily commanded, and intemperance, the fountain of lusts, is prohibited. The ninth, when relatives are mentioned, also the correlatives are included, since those cannot exist without these. Therefore, when it is commanded that some should obey, it is also commanded that some should preside over the government: and when parents are commanded to be honored, they are also commanded to do what is their duty. When men are commanded to learn the Word of God, some are also commanded to teach. The tenth, there are two tables of the Decalogue: of which the first comprehendeth in four precepts the duties which are immediately rendered unto God: the second teacheth in six precepts those which are immediately rendered unto the neighbor, but unto God mediately, that is, are rendered unto the neighbor because of God’s command and glory.

XXI. The Preface of the Decalogue

In the preface of the Decalogue, “I am the LORD,” etc., God commendeth His majesty, grace, and singular benefit unto the people.

Calvin saith: Whether thou makest the former sentence part of the first command or readest it separately, it is indifferent unto me, provided thou deniest not unto me that it is in the place of a preface unto the whole law. First, in enacting laws, care must be taken that they be not soon abrogated by contempt. Therefore, God provideth especially that the majesty of the law which He is about to enact may never come into contempt: unto which to be enacted, He useth a triple argument. He claimeth unto Himself the power and right of command, by which He may bind the chosen people unto the necessity of obeying. He setteth forth the promise of grace, by whose sweetness He may allure the same unto the study of holiness. He commemorateth the benefit, by which He may convict the Jews of ingratitude unless they respond unto His kindness.

Geneva saith: God willed, before He began the precepts themselves, to use a certain preface, both to conciliate authority, love, and reverence unto His law, and to make the hearers attentive, docile, and well-disposed.

XXII. The First Precept

By the first precept, polytheism and atheism are forbidden, and the knowledge and worship of the one true God are commanded, that is, religion.

Spanheim saith: The notation of the name is variously handed down by various authors. Religion, according unto Cicero, is derived from relegendo, that is, sacred things, by the same analogy as legion from legendo: thus, the religious are said to be those who diligently reconsidered and, as it were, reread all things which pertained unto the worship of the gods: unto Jerome and Lactantius, religion is said to be from religando, because by the duties of piety we are, as it were, bound and tied unto God: unto Augustine, both from relegando and from religendo (for reëligendo) God, whom we had lost by neglecting. Unto Macrobius, forcedly from relinquendo; as also unto Sulpitius from religando, namely, of profane things and those alien from the worship of the deity. We, by the nomenclature of religion, comprehend here in complex the internal and external worship of God, consisting partly internally in right judgment about God in the mind, and in true love of Him in the heart, partly externally, both in the profession of truth and in the practice of piety. Hence, the denomination “religious” first and properly belongeth unto persons, secondarily and transumptively unto actions and sacred things, and their circumstances, because here and now, that is, in the times and places in which sacred things and actions are performed.

Calvin saith: But true religion must precede, by which the minds are referred unto the living God: imbued with whose knowledge, they may aspire unto reverence, fear, worship His Majesty, unto embracing the communication of His goods, unto seeking help everywhere, unto recognizing and celebrating with confession of praise the magnificence of His works in all actions of life, as unto the only scope; then let perverse superstition be guarded against, by which the minds, deflected from the true God, are drawn hither and thither, as into various gods. Therefore, if we be content with one God, let us remember what was said before, that all fictitious gods are to be driven far away, and the worship which He alone claimeth for Himself is not to be torn asunder.

Ames saith: Observance is either religion or justice. This distribution, as to the thing itself, is constituted by God in the partition of the Decalogue, as explained by Christ, Matthew 22:37. The sense of the same distribution is expressed by other words, Romans 1:18, where all disobedience of man is distributed into impiety and injustice, which could not consist unless all obedience also were conversant in piety and justice, which is more expressly explained in Titus 2:12, where from those three proposed, justice and piety constitute the parts of new obedience, and temperance noteth the mode or means of rendering the same, namely, worldly lusts being denied. Unto the same also cometh that distribution of the Christian life, which is more frequently used, into holiness and justice, Luke 1:75; Ephesians 4:24, and the same is the mind of that distribution which is of charity toward God, charity toward the neighbor. Yet we use the words religion and justice, because religion is the most general word, containing all those duties which are due unto God, and most emphatic, because it expresseth that proper and distinct reason by which they are due unto God, Acts 26:5; James 1:26-27. Religion is the observance by which we render those things which directly pertain unto the honor of God, Romans 1:21, “Because that, when they knew God, they glorified Him not as God, neither were thankful.” The proper act of religion is to render honor unto God, and it is called worship, Exodus 12:25, and adoration, John 4:23. For it must in some wise contain good unto God. Otherwise, it would not be observance toward Him; but of intrinsic good, nothing can be added in God; extrinsic good, however, is honor, that is, the testimony of another’s virtue, to promote his glory or estimation, and this is all that a creature can render unto God. Therefore, a suitable or worthy estimation of God, and other acts by which estimation is manifested, constitute, as it were, the proximate matter of religion; and every honest human act, insofar as it can be referred unto the honor or glory of God, can be the matter or material object of religion. Also, one and the same act, which by reason of subjection unto the command is called obedience, by reason of the honor which it rendereth unto God, is called religion and worship. The proper mode of religious honor or worship is to subject the soul itself and the internal affections and acts of the will unto another. He who doth not render this religious worship unto God is profane; he who rendereth it unto another besides the true God is an idolater, Acts 10:26; Revelation 19:10; 22:8.

Voetius saith: We divide atheism into proper and participated. The latter is when one, by counsel, permission, command, or any other way by which one becometh a partaker of another’s sin, promoteth atheism. But that mode excelleth among others when one, by curious and malevolent disputations against his own sense, persuadeth another unto atheism, and that to obtain something from others which he believeth he cannot otherwise attain; or to appear subtle, learned, and eloquent above others. That is either direct or indirect or interpretative:

I. Direct is when one attempteth to extinguish, as far as in him lieth, all knowledge, sense, and faith of the Deity in his heart; so that he contendeth unto apistia, nay, he wisheth to have persuaded himself and others that he hath arrived at it.

II. Indirect is when one, by necessary consequence, overthroweth all knowledge and sense of God. And it is either theoretical or practical. It is gross when they either attack God, or at least the providence of God, or the fear and worship of the Deity, or draw it into doubt, or do not admit it and constantly profess it. Unto this refer the brutal ignorance of divine things: unto this the Cyclopean and fierce contempt.

III. Subtle and cloaked, or covered: when the divine attribute and what the true God is, or who that true God is, is denied by the example of the Gentiles, Mohammedans, Jews: or religion or the manner of worshiping God is indirectly denied, either in whole, or as to the principal part, or as to a great part, Psalm 94:7; Malachi 3:14; 1 Corinthians 15:32; 2 Peter 3:3-4, or at least is not cared for.

Junius saith: Religious adoration is either true or false, or Romanist. That is to be exhibited unto the omnipotent, omniscient God alone. “Thou shalt have no other gods before Me,” Exodus 20:3. “Thou shalt worship the Lord thy God, and Him only shalt thou serve,” Deuteronomy 6:13. Thus Christ repelleth Satan, Matthew 4:10, and the angel saith unto John, “Worship God,” Revelation 19:10. This is when honor due unto God alone is exhibited unto creatures. And indeed, either unto the living, as unto that supreme Pontiff, or Antichrist of Rome, who hath proceeded unto such temerity that he openly affecteth divine honors among men, while he compelleth himself to be religiously adored, to prostrate at his feet, and to kiss them, even the prelates of the supreme order, yea, and the supreme princes. Or unto the dead, and those living in heaven, where a double adoration is devised by the Papists, namely, douleia, which is promiscuous adoration, to be exhibited unto angels, saints departed, and their sepulchers, bones, tombs, statues, and pictures. Hyperdouleia, which is accustomed to be exhibited unto the Virgin Mary, unto the humanity of Christ, and unto the cross unto which He was affixed: albeit concerning this they do not sufficiently agree among themselves, as appeareth from the Acts of the Second Council of Nicaea. But they establish that the worship of latreia pertaineth unto God. That this invention of the sacrificers is sacrilegious and inept, the thing itself crieth out, for this distinction is not observed by the sacred letters, Matthew 6:24; Luke 16:13; Romans 16:18; Galatians 4:8-9; Romans 1:9; 1 Thessalonians 1:9; 1 Peter 2:16; Revelation 22:6; Romans 12:1. For douleia is also that which is due unto God, hence the Apostle frequently calleth himself doulos of God: and on the contrary, latreia is service which is rendered unto man, and namely for hire, as Suidas testifieth. But let us dismiss these. Those who introduce this distinction do not observe it. For they so adore the saints that, except for the name of God, they attribute all things in some manner unto them, omniscience, omnipotence, omnipresence, and what not? Therefore, the distinction is rendered vain, and hath nothing but vain names. What, that the saints on this earth were unwilling to be adored and worshiped, as is clear from Acts 10:26, Peter would not admit it from Cornelius. Acts 14:14-15, Paul and Barnabas reject the divine honors offered by the Lystrans, they are indignant. So it is to be thought concerning the angels. The angel forbiddeth John to adore him, Revelation 19:10; 22:8-9. Therefore, the invocation of saints and angels is impious. “How shall they call on Him in whom they have not believed?” Romans 10:14.Nor indeed could that be suitable unto Christ, unless as He is man, He were also God: for adoration is not referred unto the humanity considered by itself, but unto the Deity, unto which the flesh is hypostatically united, and unto the whole person, from the First Council of Ephesus. And that no creature is to be invoked appeareth from this, that no command concerning this matter existeth. For in the matter of religion, it is necessary to rely on the Word of God, since ethelothrēskeia is condemned by God in Scripture. “In vain do they worship Me, teaching for doctrines the commandments of men,” Matthew 15:9. Moreover, this thing lacketh example in both Testaments. Furthermore, that it is of the omnipotent nature alone to judge the motions of hearts, and to discern the phronēma and the spirit. “And He that searcheth the hearts knoweth what is the mind of the Spirit, because He maketh intercession for the saints according unto the will of God,” Romans 8:27. But Isaiah ascribeth the contrary unto the saints themselves, who saith that Abraham doth not know us, and Jacob ignorath us, Isaiah 63:16; John 8:22. Finally, that God alone is shaddai and autarkēs, Genesis 17:1; Acts 17:25. The saints are not sufficient for themselves, but are what they are by the virtue of God, and therefore that honor is sacrilegiously rendered unto them. Nor do we admit what they except here, that by God’s permission they can help: for God doth not give His honor unto another, Isaiah 42:8. But on the contrary, He commandeth all the burdened and afflicted to come unto Him, and promiseth certain rest, Matthew 11:28. Nor is there any vileness here which ought to exclude us, since Christ is present unto all sinners, even unto the thief on the cross, unto Peter the denier, unto the doubting disciples: therefore, no vileness ought to drive us unto other mediators, who, however much they may wish or be able, thou canst in no wise know. Yet if thou wishest to honor the saints, honor them therefore by the approval of God’s gifts, by grateful remembrance of their names, and by holy imitation of their manners and life, Galatians 1:24; 1 Thessalonians 5:13; Philippians 2:29; 1 Timothy 5:17; Hebrews 13:7; 1 Corinthians 11:1; Philippians 3:17; John 8:39, and Augustine, De Vera Religione. Let us therefore be fully persuaded that the true God alone is to be invoked and adored, and that not in some certain place, as was wont to be done in the Old Testament, namely, in the temple of Jerusalem, 1 Kings 9:3; 2 Chronicles 7:16; Isaiah 27:13; Psalm 99:9; Psalm 132:13-14, but everywhere in every place, as the Apostle testifieth, 1 Corinthians 1:2, and elsewhere, as Matthew 6:6; John 4:23-24.

Zuinglius saith: From these things, it can easily be gathered what further true religion requireth, and conversely, it can more easily be detected what false religion is. True religion, or piety, is that which adhereth unto the one and only God. Therefore, those who are pious hear their one Lord, who hath so torn them from the flesh and joined them unto Himself that they desire to hear His voice alone, and with the burning love of the soul they cry out, Song of Solomon 2:14, “Let Thy voice sound in my ears,” and Psalm 119:103, “How sweet are Thy words unto my taste! yea, sweeter than honey unto my mouth.” Therefore, true piety requireth that one hang upon the mouth of the Lord, that he neither hear nor receive the word of any but his spouse. False religion or piety is when one trusteth in anything other than God. Therefore, those who trust in any creature whatsoever are not truly pious.

XXIII. The Second Precept

By the second precept, idolatry and superstition are forbidden, and that God be worshiped in no other way than that in which He willeth.

Calvin saith: The end of the precept is that He willeth not that His legitimate worship be profaned by superstitious rites. Wherefore, in sum, He wholly recallth and abstracteth us from carnal observances, which our foolish mind, when it hath conceived God according unto its own grossness, is wont to devise: and thus He formeth us unto His legitimate worship, that is, spiritual and instituted by Himself. But He noteth what is the grossest vice in this transgression: external idolatry. And there are indeed two parts of the command: the former restraineth our license, that we dare not subject God, who is incomprehensible, unto our senses, or represent Him by any form. The second prohibiteth us from adoring any images for the sake of religion.

Geneva saith: Therefore, all who have ever been adorers of images as if they were sacred things, not only adorers but also makers, are once for all condemned by this precept as superstitious. Therefore, that opinion of the Greeks from some ages is foolish, who tolerate painted images but repudiate sculpted or statues made from solid matter. Ridiculous also is their ignorance who make a distinction between the Greek word eidolon and the Latin imago. Vain also is that triple distinction of religious worship into latria, dulia, and hyperdulia, partly recently devised by the Papists, partly depraved. No less damnable is their evasion, who, to excuse the crime of idolatry, say that they adore not the images themselves, but their ektypon. However, we say that not all images are forbidden by this command, but those which are instituted for the sake of religion, the religious use whereof the Word of God therefore condemneth, because it is contumelious unto God and His creatures. And since the temples of Christians are built for the sake of religious worship, it is unlawful to place in them images, which even the ancient and purer Church lacked for about four hundred years: painted walls being at length admitted with statues, and with them horrible idolomania entered, which even now cannot be extruded.

Ames saith: The parts of religion are two: natural worship and voluntary or instituted worship. This distinction is hinted at in Exodus 20:6 by those words of the second precept, “them that love Me and keep My commandments.” Natural worship is that which dependeth on the very nature of God, so that albeit we had no law divinely revealed and prescribed, yet if we had the nature of God rightly inspected and known, from the suitable contemplation of it, with the help of God’s grace, we could perceive all those things which in this part pertain unto our duty. For there is no one who rightly understandeth the nature of God but that he also necessarily acknowledgeth that God is to be believed, hoped in, loved, invoked, and heard in all things. Hence, this natural worship is simply necessary for salvation, Psalm 79:6; Jeremiah 10:25; 2 Thessalonians 1:8. For albeit we attain eternal life neither by the merit nor by any virtue of our obedience, yet this part of obedience hath so essential a connection with that faith by which we rest in Christ for eternal life that it cannot be separated from it in exercise. Hence also this worship was, is, and will be one and the same, or immutable, 1 John 2:7, “The old commandment which ye had from the beginning.” Natural worship is commanded in the first commandment, not only as it is internal, but also as it is external. Instituted worship is a means ordained by the will of God for exercising and promoting natural worship. All such means instituted by God are indicated in the second precept by the prohibition of all opposite means of worship devised by men, under the title of graven image and likeness: which, since they were formerly the chief inventions of men depraving the worship of God, are most aptly placed (by a perpetual synecdoche in the Decalogue) in the place of all inventions of human ingenuity pertaining unto worship. This is indicated by those words of the precept, “Thou shalt not make unto thee,” that is, from thine own brain or judgment. For albeit that particle “unto thee” sometimes is redundant or hath another force, yet here the most accurate brevity of these precepts excludeth redundancy, and it is manifest from other places of Scripture looking unto the same that the vanity of human thoughts is to be excluded: as Amos 5:26, “Which ye made unto yourselves.” Numbers 15:39, “That ye seek not after your own heart and your own eyes, after which ye use to go a whoring.” The same is also declared by the universality of that prohibition which is explained in the precept by distribution: of those things which are in heaven above, or which are in the earth beneath, or which are in the waters under the earth. For no one except God Himself can either understand what will be pleasing unto Him, or adjoin unto any worship that virtue by which it can become efficacious and useful unto us: nor can anything be honorific unto God which doth not proceed from Himself as its author; nor finally do we read that such power was ever given by God unto anyone to institute any worship at his own discretion, Matthew 15:9, “But in vain they do worship Me, teaching for doctrines the commandments of men.” The sin which is committed in voluntary worship is generally called superstition. Superstition is when undue worship is exhibited unto God. For in superstition, God is always the object and in some wise the end, but the worship itself is illicit. Undue worship is said either with respect unto the mode or measure, or with respect unto the matter and substance of the worship. In the former way, the Pharisees sinned concerning the Sabbath, when they urged its observation, as to external cessation, beyond the mode and measure constituted by God. And in the latter way, the same also sinned by observing and urging their own traditions, Mark 7:8. If there be idols which are worshiped in the place of God, that is idolatry which is adverse unto the first precept; but when the true God is worshiped unto an image or in an image, this is idolatry which is adverse unto the second precept.

Maresius saith: It remaineth to be examined whether it be lawful to place images in sacred places where the assemblies of the faithful are held. Some affirm that it is lawful, provided that their adoration be prohibited. But in my judgment, it is not to be committed that they be had in temples. First, because the thing is full of danger, and experience hath taught unto what at length men have fallen from their sight, when they saw them placed in temples; they adored them. Certainly, the way which leadeth unto idolatry ought to be cut off from the faithful. Augustine writeth religiously and most beautifully concerning this matter in Psalm 113: “When images are placed in a high place, or on some platform, a depraved affection is produced in the minds, by which the devil is invited to mix himself.” Likewise, Epistle 49 unto Deogratias was of the same opinion. And indeed, we see that this hath happened. Nor will I omit that the same Father in Sermon 6 on the words of the Lord on the mount: “They declare,” he saith, “in what place and estimation they hold the idol when they place an altar for it. For unless they thought that it had either deity or something of divinity in itself, they would not erect an altar for it.” Therefore, by this opinion of Augustine, almost all the temples of the Papists are condemned, where altars are almost always conjoined with idols. Moreover, by the example of the holy Epiphanius, it can be proven that they are not to be had in temples. He, when he was traveling and had come unto a certain village called Anablatha, saw a burning lamp as he passed by, and having asked what place it was, heard that it was a church or oratory of the faithful; wherefore, he entered to pray unto God there. But he saw a veil hanging, on which was painted the image of a man, as if of Christ or of a holy man. Therefore, when he had seen in the church, against the authority of the Scriptures, the sign of a man hanging, he both took down and tore that veil, and gave counsel unto the custodians that they should wrap a dead pauper in it and carry him out. Then he wrote unto John, the bishop of Jerusalem, unto whom the care of that place pertained, that henceforth he should take care that veils of this kind, contrary unto what religion alloweth, should not be had in the church of Christ. And that epistle was of such weight unto Jerome that he did not disdain to make it Latin; which, unless he had been of our opinion, he would by no means have done. Also, the Second Council of Ephesus condemned images. But it is not received, and indeed rightly, since it favored Nestorius and Eutyches. This is the fate not only of human things but also frequently of ecclesiastical things, that evil things have good things mixed with them: whence it followeth afterward that not only evil things but also good things are rejected together. Thus, we see that it happened unto some Greek emperors who destroyed images. For Philippicus the First, Leo the Third, Constantine, and Leo the Fourth, because they were Monothelites, what they rightly established on the other hand concerning images was repudiated. Which also happeneth today, when, because of the corrupt morals of the Evangelicals, their pure doctrine is exploded. Also, the Council of Elvira condemned images: in which it was decreed that no image should be painted on the walls of temples: lest that which is painted should exist, which is adored. Peresius, when he saw himself pressed by the opinion of those fathers, perhaps inserteth: they did not will that all images should be removed, but those which were now being made deformed on the walls, not likewise on cloths and tables. But afterward, when he perceived that this was frivolous, he deviseth that such paintings could rightly have been removed for a time, because men then worshiped them with the adoration of latria, and by his opinion, he opposeth Gregory, who decreed that they were not therefore to be removed, but rather that men were to be admonished not to adore them. Peresius also establisheth that in the same manner and way, Epiphanius is to be excused.

XXIV. The Third Precept

The third precept forbiddeth the rash and unholy use of the name of God and commandeth that the name of God be had reverently and religiously in every thing or speech.

Geneva saith: But the reason why this command was rather conceived in the formula of prohibiting than of commanding is that it is not always necessary what is specifically commanded here: but what is forbidden here is always unlawful. The name of God is not to be restricted unto some certain appellation or certain syllables, but comprehendeth whatsoever can be said of God and pertaineth unto His knowledge and glory. Therefore, in sum, by synecdoche, it is commanded by this precept that in every use of this life we have the glory of God before our eyes, and therefore whatever, whether obliquely or directly, whether imprudently or designedly, redoundeth unto His ignominy is forbidden. To take the name of God is to make mention of God, which the Lord, forbidding to be done rashly or about nothing, finally irreverently, much more condemneth whatever is admitted here with greater temerity or irreverence. Therefore, all abuse of the divine Word for magical tricks and incantations, and other things of that kind, is especially condemned by this precept as a most execrable thing. But specifically, all abuse of swearing is forbidden by this command. We call an oath the invocation of God as witness and avenger, which, that it may be legitimate, requireth three things: truth, justice, judgment.

Ames saith: The mode of worship in general is the legitimate use of all those things which pertain unto God. But legitimate use consisteth in this, that all things which pertain unto worship are so handled as befitteth the divine majesty. For since by the third precept it is forbidden that thou take not the name of God in vain, by the name of God are understood all those things by which God is made known unto us or revealeth Himself, just as men among themselves are wont to be known by their names: so that the name of God embraceth all those things which pertain unto the worship of God, whether natural or instituted, Acts 9:15, “That he may bear My name before the Gentiles.” Deuteronomy 12:5, “The place which the LORD shall choose to place His name there.” Micah 4:5, “We will walk in the name of the LORD our God.” Malachi 1:11-12, “My name shall be great among the Gentiles.” But to take this name in vain is either to take it rashly, that is, either without any proposed end or without a just and suitable end; or to take it in vain, that is, not in the manner which is required for a just end, namely, the honor of God; at the same time, it is also commanded that we sanctify the name of God, that is, that we use all sacred things in that manner which befitteth their sanctity and dignity, Isaiah 1:13. A certain general reverence of God is necessary for all obedience; which respecteth the authority of God commanding; but this is proper unto the acts of religion, which hath respect unto the sanctity of those things about which we are conversant. This reverence containeth two things:

  1. A just estimation of the excellence of such things.
  2. Fear of too much familiarity, by which such things might be unworthily handled by us.

Devotion containeth two things:

  1. A certain singular promptitude to perform all those things which pertain unto the worship of God, Psalm 108:2-3, “I will awake early. I will praise Thee, O Lord, among the people.”
  2. A suitable delight in performing them, Isaiah 58:13, “If thou call the Sabbath a delight.”

Walaeus saith: It is asked here whether it be lawful for Christians to use the name of God in oaths. The Essenes formerly denied it, as may be seen in Josephus, Book 2, De Bello Judaico, Chapter 7. The Anabaptists deny it. The monks also establish greater perfection here if one doth not swear, and they refer it also unto the evangelical counsels from Matthew 5:33. But we say that not only under the Old but also under the New Testament, legitimate oaths are lawful.

Response:

  1. It is proven because an oath is of the law of nature: for all nations in graver matters have used it for the confirmation of truth. And from this very third precept, it is also manifest, since the contrary is always commanded in a negative precept.
