As it is expressly commanded by God, Deuteronomy 6:13; 10:20, “Thou shalt fear the LORD thy God, and serve Him, and shalt swear by His name.” “For He is thy praise.” Psalm 63:11, “The king shall rejoice in God; every one that sweareth by Him shall glory.” But Christ came not to destroy the law of nature or the moral law, but to fulfill it, Matthew 5:17. Yea, he who shall break one of the least of these commandments and shall teach men so, he shall be called the least in the kingdom of heaven, verse 19.
  2. It is proven from the divine promises made in the prophets concerning the New Testament, as Isaiah 45:22-23, “Look unto Me, and be ye saved, all the ends of the earth. I have sworn by Myself, the word is gone out of My mouth in righteousness, and shall not return, that unto Me every knee shall bow, every tongue shall swear.” And 65:16, speaking of the time of the New Testament, “He who blesseth himself in the earth shall bless himself in the God of truth; and he that sweareth in the earth shall swear by the God of truth.” See also Jeremiah 4:2; 12:16,
  3. It is proven from examples. Thus, the Apostle citeth this place, Romans 14:11, “As I live, saith the Lord, every knee shall bow unto Me.” And Hebrews 7:20, he saith that the priesthood of the New Testament was made by God with an oath. See also other examples in the New Testament, Romans 9:1, “I say the truth in Christ, I lie not, my conscience also bearing me witness in the Holy Ghost.” Likewise, 2 Corinthians 1:23, “Moreover I call God for a record upon my soul.” So Romans 1:9; Philippians 1:8,“For God is my record, how greatly I long after you all in the bowels of Jesus Christ.” Likewise, the angel sweareth by Him that liveth forever and ever, Revelation 10:6. And these show that it is false what the Romanists say, that it is an evangelical counsel not to swear, or that it is of greater perfection in this life, because thus they would establish that those monks are more perfect than the Apostle Paul, yea, than the angels, yea, than God, which is blasphemous.
  4. Finally, Hebrews 6:16, the Apostle testifieth that an oath for confirmation is an end of all strife. The end whereof in the New Testament is praised; therefore, it also is praised.

Objection: But the place Matthew 5:34, “Ye have heard that it hath been said by them of old time, Thou shalt not forswear thyself, but shalt perform unto the Lord thine oaths: but I say unto you, Swear not at all.” And James 5:12, “But above all things, my brethren, swear not, neither by heaven, neither by the earth, neither by any other oath.”

Response: As to the place Matthew 5:34, we say that Christ doth not prohibit every kind of oath, but rash oath, and that which is customary in the common conversation of men: which they thought was lawful, provided that they did not swear by God Himself. As is to be seen in Matthew 23:16, “Woe unto you, ye blind guides, which say, Whosoever shall swear by the temple, it is nothing; but whosoever shall swear by the gold of the temple, he is a debtor! Ye fools and blind: for whether is greater, the gold, or the temple that sanctifieth the gold?” Where they expressly affirm that some oaths bind, some do not bind. Christ, on the contrary, affirmeth that all oaths bind, made concerning things not unlawful, even if they are not made by God Himself: since in those creatures also the name of God is violated: and besides, He teacheth that one ought not to swear at all, namely, neither rashly nor by creatures. But this is proven:

  1. From the connection of those words: “But I say unto you, Swear not at all, neither by heaven, neither by the earth.” He doth not add, neither by God Himself, which especially was to be added if Christ had prohibited every oath.
  2. From this, that He saith, “But let your communication be, Yea, yea; Nay, nay: for whatsoever is more than these cometh of evil.” But the Apostles add more, but not superfluous, as we have heard.

It followeth that we inquire what kind of oath can be rendered by Christians. Therefore, the first condition is that one swear by the true God and Christ our Savior. Which is proven:

  1. Because an oath is defined as a religious action by which God is invoked as a witness of those things which we say or promise, whether that be done simply or with execration. As we see, Romans 1:9, “For God is my witness, whom I serve with my spirit in the gospel of His Son.” And Philippians 1:8, “For God is my record, how greatly I long after you all in the bowels of Jesus Christ.” Romans 9:1, “I say the truth in Christ, I lie not.” And 2 Corinthians 1:23, “Moreover I call God for a record upon my soul.” Likewise, throughout in the Old Testament, “God do so unto me, and more also.” Thus, the angel sweareth by Him that liveth forever, Revelation 10:6.
  2. And everywhere other oaths are condemned, as Jeremiah 5:7, “They have sworn by them that are no gods.” Likewise, Deuteronomy 6:13, “Thou shalt swear by His name.” Isaiah 65:16, “He that sweareth in the earth shall swear by the God of truth,” that is, the true God.
  3. Because unto God properly belong the properties required in an oath; as, that He is the searcher of hearts, and therefore alone the true witness of our assertion, 2 Corinthians 11:31, “The God and Father of our Lord Jesus Christ, which is blessed forevermore, knoweth that I lie not.” So above, “God is my witness.” He alone can punish the delinquents when they secretly deceive, or are above human punishments.

    4. Objection: But we see that certain saints have sworn by creatures, as Genesis 42:15, Joseph saith, “By the life of Pharaoh.” Likewise, Hannah, 1 Samuel 1:26, “As thy soul liveth, my lord.”

    Response: Some respond that in these examples there can be some imperfection, and therefore they are not to be imitated. But it is not necessary that these be condemned: because they are not true oaths, since here there is no invocation; but we say that they are serious asseverations, from the comparison of things certain or dear unto us. Unto this is to be referred the place 1 Timothy 5:21, “I charge thee before God, and the Lord Jesus Christ, and the elect angels.” As also the place Deuteronomy 4:26, “I call heaven and earth to witness against you this day.”

    Question: It is asked here whether at least oaths not to be rendered by the true God can be exacted, or admitted by true Christians, if an oath is exacted or to be exacted by others?

    Response: That this can be done between persons who are not mutually subject unto each other is shown by the example of Laban, Genesis 31:53, where Jacob, entering into a covenant with Laban, sweareth by the fear of his father, but Laban by the gods of Nahor: so throughout under the New Testament it was done.

  4. When covenants are made between those who are unfaithful, as also between the Romanists and ours.It is asked whether it be lawful to conceive oaths in ambiguous words. This the Anabaptists defend, and the Jesuits in their mental reservations. But besides that this fighteth with natural equity and justice itself, as Cicero, Aristotle, and other Gentile ethicists rightly establish; it also fighteth:
  5. With open places of Scripture, Matthew 5:37, “But let your communication be, Yea, yea; Nay, nay: for whatsoever is more than these cometh of evil.” Likewise, James 5:12. Likewise, 2 Corinthians 1:18, “But as God is true, our word toward you was not yea and nay.” Leviticus 19:11, “Ye shall not steal, neither deal falsely, neither lie one to another.” Ephesians 4:25, “Wherefore putting away lying, speak every man truth with his neighbor.” Psalm 12:2,”The LORD shall cut off all flattering lips.” Therefore, if in common speech the word cannot be ambiguous or uncertain, much less in oaths, where God is invoked as a witness of truth.
  6. All examples of Scripture teach this. The example of Peter simulating is condemned, Galatians 2:14, “But when I saw that they walked not uprightly according unto the truth of the gospel, I said unto Peter before them all, If thou, being a Jew, livest after the manner of Gentiles, and not as do the Jews, why compellest thou the Gentiles to live as do the Jews?” See also Jeremiah 9:5, “And they will deceive every one his neighbor, and will not speak the truth: they have taught their tongue to speak lies, and weary themselves to commit iniquity.” Likewise, 2 Corinthians 4:2,”But have renounced the hidden things of dishonesty, not walking in craftiness, nor handling the word of God deceitfully; but by manifestation of the truth commending ourselves unto every man’s conscience in the sight of God.” When we read these things in the Holy Scriptures, not because we believe them done, do we also believe them to be done, lest we violate the precepts while we everywhere follow examples: Augustine on the examples of lying in the Scriptures. And chapter 20, “It is not a lie when the truth is hidden by silence, but when falsehood is uttered by speaking: examples of the former for good ends are found in the Scriptures; of the latter, none except in those who are to be reproved.”
  7. It is proven from the conditions which Holy Scripture requireth in every legitimate oath: namely, Jeremiah 4:2,”And thou shalt swear, The LORD liveth, in truth, in judgment, and in righteousness”: in truth, because one must swear with a sincere mind: in judgment, because nothing rashly or lightly: in righteousness, because nothing except what is honest and just.
  8. From the scope of an oath, which is the end of all strife, Hebrews 6:16. But this end cannot be had in captious and ambiguous oaths.
  9. A lie is a false signification of speech with the intention of deceiving: therefore, here a double truth is required:
    1. With the thing about which thou speakest, that thou pronounce as it truly is.
    2. With the intention of the speaker.
  10. The equivocations of the Jesuits are refuted by absurdities:
    1. In vain would God have set laws against lying: for anyone could easily excuse this by some mental reservation.
    2. The martyrs could easily have escaped by such tricks.
    3. The judge could never express sincere truth unto anyone if these were lawful.
    4. There could be no sincere faith in contracts, covenants, etc.

Objection: But Christ in Luke 24:28 “made as though He would have gone further,” when He accompanied the disciples unto Emmaus, albeit He intended to stay with them there.

Response:

  1. Here there is no oath.
  2. Nor is there even an assertion that He would go further.
  3. He made as though, that is, He so ordered His journey as if He would go further. But He could have willed to go further indeed, unless He had been pressed by the disciples unto the contrary.

Finally, we do not say that men always ought to reveal their whole counsel at once, but they can conceal part, as Samuel when he came unto Bethlehem to anoint David, 1 Samuel 16:2-3, “And the LORD said, Take an heifer with thee, and say, I am come to sacrifice unto the LORD.”

Ames saith: Since testimony is either of a thing done or to be done, therefore an oath confirming testimony is distinguished into assertory and promissory. An assertory oath is concerning a thing past or present, 2 Corinthians 1:23. A promissory oath, under which also the comminatory is contained, is concerning a thing future, 1 Samuel 20:12-13. An assertory oath, because it is concerning a thing already done, doth not oblige unto doing anything, but only affirmeth the truth of the thing already done. A promissory oath hath in itself the force of an assertory oath, insofar as it testifieth unto the present firm intention of the mind: but it obligeth moreover unto doing that which is testified to be intended. But it obligeth only insofar as one can oblige himself, that is, unto that which both in fact and in right he can perform, and therefore it ought always to be concerning a lawful and possible thing. Such an oath obligeth unto its fulfillment, albeit the oath itself as to its mode was unlawful, or the thing promised bringeth loss unto the promiser, Joshua 9:19; Psalm 15:4. But if the oath be against the commands of God, it doth not oblige: because an oath ought not to be a bond of iniquity.

Walaeus saith: It is asked whether it be lawful to make vows under the New Testament, and whether those made oblige. Response: Those things are of two kinds; for either their circumstances alone are free, but the substance itself is commanded; or not only the circumstances but also the things themselves are left free by God under the New Testament. Monastic vows are almost three: namely, the vow of obedience, the vow of poverty, and the vow of chastity, unto which the Jesuits add the vow of mission. They call the vow of obedience that by which they bind themselves to observe the rules of this or that order, namely, of Francis, Bernard, Dominic, etc., concerning such clothing, such food to be used, such hours of praying, fasting; in these, each order varieth: for they have their peculiar institutions. But we, albeit we grant that for the sake of order in every society of men some things can be instituted for the conservation of discipline, yet we deny that such institutions are lawful to bind consciences with the opinion of divine worship. For:

  1. This fighteth with the places proposed before concerning the liberty of indifferent things.
  2. With the saying of Christ, Matthew 15:9.
  3. Because the Apostle expressly saith, 1 Timothy 4:1, that it is the doctrine of demons forbidding to marry, commanding to abstain from meats which God hath created to be received with thanksgiving, etc. And that the kingdom of God doth not consist in those things, Romans 14:17, “For the kingdom of God is not meat and drink; but righteousness, and peace, and joy in the Holy Ghost.”

XXV. The Fourth Precept

By the fourth precept, the observance of the Sabbath is enjoined, which, instituted from the beginning of the world, renewed in the Decalogue, changed to the first day, the Lord’s Day, by the example of Christ and the Apostles, consists in the rest of that day and the sanctification joined to the rest, according to the morality of the precept.

Walaeus saith: The word “remember” or recordare is placed here first, that God may immediately at the beginning indicate that the observation of this precept is to be seriously recalled to mind; because men by nature are prone to procure their own works rather than God’s. And although it is not badly noted by others, as we shall say more broadly hereafter, that God uses the word of remembrance here because the observation of the Sabbath is not first instituted here, but its use, already neglected or obscured, is recalled to memory and more seriously commended. To sanctify here is the same as to apply or employ for holy uses: as it is said afterward of God Himself, that He blessed that day and sanctified it; that is, destined and ordained it for holy uses or His worship. Concerning the form and manner of which sanctification, more will also be said in the progress. Concerning the mode of sanctification, two things are said: first, one’s own works are closed in six days: then divine works are prescribed to all on this day. As to one’s own works, it says of them: “Six days shalt thou labor, and do all thy work.” By the word “work,” avodah or melachah, are not directly understood the vicious works of men; because they are never conceded by God, but servile works, avad, to serve; by which, namely, each one according to the reason of his vocation exercises his livelihood; which by Christ, Luke 21:34, and by Paul, 1 Corinthians 6:3, are called biōtika, because by them this natural life is sustained. Two things are comprehended in the sanctification of this day: first, the rest itself from works: second, the application of that day to holy uses.

Geneva saith: This precept was not first enacted when God gave the law on Mount Sinai, but in the very creation of the world, even before the fall of man. For even if man had not fallen, he would have needed some polity of external divine worship for the human race, the reason of which polity He Himself constituted, then already condemning all ethelothrēskeia. The supervening fall caused that God, renewing this precept, which had gradually been abolished among men, brought forward other reasons for this precept.

Walaeus saith: Genesis 2:2-3, “And God finished on the seventh day His work which He had made; and He rested on the seventh day from all His work which He had made. And God blessed the seventh day, and sanctified it: because that in it He had rested from all His work which God created and made.” Which are the same words as those repeated in the fourth precept itself. To which place, which greatly presses those of the contrary opinion, it is excepted that these things are said here by prolepsis, namely, that God sanctified this day, not when He ceased from His works, but when He gave the manna, Exodus 16, and when He enacted the law through Moses, Exodus 20, because the enactment of the law (they say) preceded the writing of the book of Genesis. The words of Gomarus are: “These words are inserted by Moses in this place, Genesis 2:2-3, not as if they were done at the same time; but to show that this history of the seventh day of the perfect world and divine rest was to be retained by the perpetual memory of the Israelites.” But I ask all those who will read these words without prejudice whether they can be understood otherwise than of a thing which happened when God finished His work: not of a thing which happened two thousand and four hundred years later? Let the words be examined; I wonder that the contrary can seem true to anyone; namely, that the sense is, God rested on the seventh day from His works, but two thousand years later, at length He blessed it by the donation of manna, and sanctified it. Thus, God would not have blessed that Sabbath on which He rested, nor sanctified it, but that which was to come after so many centuries of years. But the relation itself and the definite article hashvi’i show that Moses speaks of this very Sabbath on which God rested.

Ames saith: Neither the purpose of God nor the mere foundation of the thing suffices to found and sustain such a phrase concerning sanctification and blessing. For by this reason, it could have been said that God sanctified water, bread, and wine into the sacraments of the new covenant from the time He gave the promise concerning the bruising of the serpent’s head through the seed of the woman, Genesis 3:15, for then it was God’s purpose to seal that covenant of grace with such seals, the foundation of which sealing was also placed partly in the promise itself and partly in the creation of those things which could actually be employed for such sealing. And by such a foundation placed in the first creation, the Prophet gathers a perpetual rule and law, Malachi 2:15, “And did not He make one? Yet had He the residue of the Spirit. And wherefore one? That He might seek a godly seed.” So likewise it is lawful for us: Did not God rest on the seventh day? But why the seventh? That He might sanctify the seventh day to God. This seems to be the argumentation of the Apostle, Hebrews 4:3-8, which is such: Mention is made in the Old Testament of a double rest of which the pious were partakers in this life: one was of the Sabbath, the other of the land of Canaan: but David, promising rest in Psalm 95, does not speak of the rest of the Sabbath, because that was from the beginning of the world, nor of the rest in the land of Canaan, because that was past, not to be expected today: therefore, he understands a certain third rest, that is, eternal in heaven.

The most solemn time of worship is now the first day of each week, which is called the Lord’s Day, Revelation 1:10; 1 Corinthians 16:2. The Lord’s Day is so called for the same reason that the sacred supper of the Eucharist is called the Lord’s Supper, 1 Corinthians 11:20, because, namely, it was instituted by our Lord Jesus Christ, and ought to be referred to the same Lord in end and use. That the last day of the week has now been changed into the first day, this was not done by human authority, but by divine. For He alone could change the day of the Sabbath who is the Lord of the Sabbath, Christ, Mark 2:28, whence also that first day which succeeded is properly called the Lord’s Day. If this Lord’s Day be conceded to have been of Apostolic institution, yet the authority on which it rests is nonetheless divine, because the Apostles were moved by the divine Spirit no less in holy institutions than in the doctrine of the Gospel itself, to be proposed either by word or by writings. Since also that institution rested on no singular occasion, to last only for a time, by which it can be rendered temporary, it necessarily follows that the mind of the institutors was that the observation of this day should be of perpetual and immutable right. Yet it is more likely that Christ Himself in His own person was the author of this institution:

  1. Because Christ was no less faithful in ordering the whole house or Church of God as to all things generally necessary and useful than was Moses, Hebrews 3:2,6. But that the observation of this day is generally useful and in some wise necessary for the churches of Christ, no Christian can with any reason deny.
  2. Because Christ Himself after the resurrection often appeared to His disciples gathered together in one place on this very day, John 20:19.
  3. Because He poured out the Holy Spirit upon them on this very day, Acts 2:1-4.
  4. In the practice of the churches in the time of the Apostles, when mention is made of the observation of this first day, Acts 20:7; 1 Corinthians 16:2, it is not commemorated as some recent institution, but as a thing long since received among all the disciples of Christ.
  5. The Apostles delivered to the churches in all things those things which they had received from Christ, 1 Corinthians 11:23.
  6. This institution could not be deferred even for one week after Christ’s death, so that the law concerning the sanctification of one day out of each week might remain firm, according to the determination of God Himself; which law, however, it was shown before to be of perpetual right. For the Jewish Sabbath, with respect to the determination it had to the seventh day, was abrogated in Christ: for that the Apostles are read to have been present at the assemblies of the Jews on that day of the Sabbath for some time afterward, Acts 13:14; 16:13; 17:2; 18:4, they did this chiefly for this reason, because then there was the best opportunity of preaching the Gospel to the Jews: just as also afterward the Apostle especially desired to be at Jerusalem on the day of Pentecost, Acts 20:16, because at that time there was to be the greatest concourse of Jews in that place.
  7. If the institution of the Lord’s Day had been deferred until the Apostles had made secession from the Jews and had their assemblies separately, Acts 18:6-7; 19:8, as some will, then throughout the whole interval of time which intervened between Christ’s death and that separation, which was more than three years, the fourth precept would have obliged no one to the observation of any certain day; because the Jewish day was already abolished, and according to this opinion, no new one was substituted for it, and thus there would have been only nine precepts in force throughout that whole space.
  8. The reason itself of this change confirms the same, which by all consenting is referred to the resurrection of Christ: because, namely, on that day the creation of the new world or of the world to come, Hebrews 2:5, in which all things are made new, 2 Corinthians 5:17, was perfected, so that God now rested from His greatest work and labor by Christ rising from the dead. Therefore, just as in the beginning of creation, when God rested from His works, then He blessed and sanctified that day on which He rested, so also it was fitting that on that very day on which Christ rested from His labors, He Himself should sanctify the same day. Nor is it easily to be rejected what is urged by some ancients from Psalm 118:24, “This is the day which the LORD hath made”: for in that place it is treated of the resurrection of Christ, by Christ Himself interpreting, Matthew 21:42.
  9. It was also most agreeable that the day of worship under the New Testament should be instituted by Him by whom the worship itself was instituted, and from whom all blessing and grace in all worship is to be expected; rightly therefore Athanasius (Homily on the Seed) says, “The Lord transferred the day of the Sabbath to the Lord’s Day.”

For the right observation of this day, two things are necessary: rest, and the sanctification of that rest. The rest which is required is cessation from all work that would place an impediment to the exercises of divine worship. Therefore, on this day, we must abstain:

  1. From all those works which are properly called servile: for since such works were formerly expressly excluded in all other more solemn feasts, Leviticus 23:7-8,25,35-36; Numbers 28:25, much more were they excluded from the Sabbath. But by servile works, it is plainly ridiculous to understand sins, or good works done for hire, or for reward (in the manner of servants) (as some do with a certain allegorical play): for sins are not prohibited and illicit only at certain times, but always and everywhere: nor does it pertain to the fourth precept to deal with prohibiting all sins, although this can be conceded in some sense, that various sins receive some aggravation if they are committed on so holy a day; Isaiah 58:4. Also, those evil works which are done from fear or from purely servile hope, with respect to that mode, take on the same nature as other sins. But servile works properly are those to which servants or servile men are wont to be employed: such as mechanical arts, and all those things for which great bodily labor is required: to plow, to dig:
  2. Besides such works, all our own works are also prohibited on this day: as is gathered from the opposite concession, which is had in the fourth precept, “Six days shalt thou labor, and do all thy work.” Whence it is to be gathered from the following words, “On the Sabbath day thou shalt not do any work,” that all those works are prohibited which are properly called ours, although they are not strictly speaking servile or mechanical. Yet here are excepted:
    1. All those works which are of common honesty. For since, as always elsewhere, so especially on that day which is singularly dedicated to divine worship, we ought to behave and act honestly and becomingly, all those things which simply pertain to that are understood to be permitted.
    2. Those which are imposed on us by some singular necessity, Matthew 12:11. Yet in this number are not to be reckoned those things which men make or feign to be necessary for themselves; but those which by God’s providence suddenly appear necessary and unavoidable: that is, when such necessity urges as the Scripture itself approves as a sufficient cause for doing something common.
    3. All those works which directly pertain to the worship and glory of God, Matthew 12:5; John 5:8-9. For in this case, those works which are by nature servile pass into the nature of sacred works, and are not properly our works, but God’s works.

This rest, although in itself absolutely considered is not, nor ever was, any part of worship; yet as it is commanded by God, as something necessary for His worship, and is referred to it, to that extent it is part of that observance which pertains to religion and the worship of God. The sanctification of this rest and day is the singular application of ourselves to worship God on that day: which rests on those very phrases, “He sanctified that day,” “The Sabbath is the LORD’s to thy God.” This public worship especially ought to be regarded, whence also it is called the Sabbath a holy convocation, Leviticus 23:3; Acts 13:14; 15:21; 16:13. But that public convocation of the Church both before and after noon on the Lord’s Day ought to be held, appears sufficiently from the double burnt offering of the Sabbath, morning and evening, Numbers 28:9. But also the remaining part of the day ought to be spent in exercises of piety: for although the burnt offering was formerly peculiar to the Sabbath, yet the continual or daily burnt offering with its drink offering was not to be omitted, Numbers 28:10. Also, the public worship itself, since it is to be celebrated most solemnly, necessarily requires those exercises of reading Scripture, meditation, prayers, holy conversations, and contemplation of God’s works, by which we may be made more ready for public worship, and it may also be rendered truly effectual in us.

Walaeus saith: It is to be noted, from the force and analogy of the precept, that not just some part of the day, but the whole day is to be sanctified to the Lord. For the words are clear, “Remember the Sabbath day, to keep it holy.” And again, “Six days shalt thou labor, but the seventh day is the Sabbath of the LORD thy God.” And that here the mode may be more diligently set, it is to be observed that the Sabbath day is not only to be celebrated in public assemblies; but also at home, in each one’s house, it is to be sanctified: as the words of the precept are clear, “Remember the Sabbath day, to keep it holy.” And Leviticus 23:3, it is also clearly expressed, “On the seventh day is the Sabbath of rest, a holy convocation; ye shall do no work therein: it is the Sabbath of the LORD in all your dwellings.” This also in this precept is certainly moral in respect: namely, that in the preceding days we so order all our affairs, as far as possible, that through their neglect we may not be hindered from the right sanctification of this day. Indeed, this is required by God’s command in all Christian assemblies, that these public exercises of piety may not be deprived of their due fruit, that, I say, the mind may also be rightly prepared for the same sanctification: as the wise man generally commands, Ecclesiastes 4:17, “Keep thy foot when thou goest to the house of God.” And Christ, Matthew 5:23. Which words, spoken by Christ concerning the external worship of the Old Testament, are to be studiously observed also concerning the external worship of the New Testament in hearing the word and the use of the sacraments and prayers, as no Christian has ever denied: lest that happen to them which God threatens to the Israelites, Isaiah 1, and elsewhere frequently in the Prophets, that our assemblies and sacrifices may be a loathing and abomination to the LORD; lest finally, by the thorns and cares of this age, by which the heart of man is besieged at that time, the increase and fruit of the divine word may be intercepted from our souls, as Christ teaches in the parable of the sower, Matthew 13:22, etc.

That this precept is merely ceremonial, and therefore entirely abolished by the coming of Christ, is almost the opinion today of the Anabaptists, who, under the pretext of Christian liberty, contend that any works are lawful on any days; and then especially are wont to be busy in our public affairs when others think they should be free for divine worship. Although among them some also then attend sermons and sacred things, because the opportunity for business with those who think otherwise is not so great then. This opinion of the Anabaptists, plainly agreeing with the Socinian, is expressed by them in their recently published Confession, Article 9, and in the second part of the defense, page 95. But that this opinion is erroneous is demonstrated by the following arguments, besides other arguments also. For first, the fourth precept is part of the Decalogue, in which nothing merely ceremonial is commanded, since the law of the Decalogue is a moral and eternal law: as Deuteronomy 10:4, the same law inscribed by God on two tables, and comprising ten words (not nine only), is asserted. To which external writing, by the Apostle Paul, is opposed the inscription by the Holy Spirit on fleshly hearts, 2 Corinthians 3:3,7, which internal inscription contains the new man, who is created after God in righteousness and true holiness. And therefore that inscription by the Holy Spirit comprises the same righteousness and holiness internally, which the law of the Decalogue externally prescribed in those ten words, but could not inscribe on the heart, because it was destitute of the efficacy of the Holy Spirit. Whence that whole law is called the ministry of death and condemnation; but the Gospel the ministry of the Spirit and of righteousness, ibid., verses 8 and 9. The same morality and perpetuity of this whole law is further demonstrated from the sum of the law, which Christ proposes, Matthew 22:37, “Thou shalt love the Lord thy God with all thy heart,” etc., and “thy neighbor as thyself.” Which is the sum of the whole moral law, from which no one has excluded the fourth precept except absurdly: just as neither from the curse which is annexed to the law, Galatians 3, “Cursed is every one that continueth not in all things which are written.” Add to this what is asserted by the Apostle James, James 2:10, “Whosoever shall keep the whole law, and yet offend in one point, he is guilty of all”: which pronouncement the Apostle applies to the Christians to whom he writes, and whom he calls brethren; the truth of which cannot stand unless that also under the New Testament has place concerning the transgression of the fourth precept. For otherwise, if in this precept there is nothing moral, he who does not keep it would not be guilty of violating the law, but rather a right observer of it, and a true assertor of Christian liberty. The same as is said by us is proven from the very words of the precept, its reasons, and its end, among which many are not ceremonial, but moral; such as the operation of six days, which is conceded by this precept, and cannot be referred to ceremony alone: nor therefore is the exemption of the seventh day to be referred to ceremony alone. The sanctification itself, which is commanded on this day, is not a ceremony; because it would have been abolished by the death of Christ: and therefore no day would be to be sanctified by us for divine worship; since it is unlawful to reduce ceremonial things to use. Just as circumcision, formerly to be celebrated on the eighth day, cannot now be recalled to use among Christians on any day. Finally, the rest and respiration (as God speaks, Deuteronomy 5, of sons, servants, beasts, etc.) is not merely ceremonial, but manifestly contains a moral object in itself. Just as also the example of God resting from His works, and the memory of the creation of things, and the like, cannot be referred to ceremony alone, which is a shadow of things to come, or looked to Christ as its body. Just as also the proximate end, namely, the knowledge and celebration of God the Creator, and the consideration of the works of creation, cannot be referred to ceremony. Since therefore all these things cannot be merely ceremonial, it evidently follows that this fourth precept is not to be reckoned among the merely ceremonial. To which is added the consent of all nations, who have always prescribed some time for the worship of their gods.

Ames saith: Indeed, what is commanded in the fourth precept is not of the same degree and mode of moral nature as those things which are commanded in almost all the other precepts, as being of positive law, not natural; whence also it is that, since the first three precepts were proposed negatively, forbidding those vices to which we are prone from the depravity of our nature, this fourth precept is first proposed affirmatively, judging and commanding that which in this part pertains to our duty, and afterward negatively, forbidding those things which are repugnant to this duty. Which is also (in part) the reason for that admonition which is singularly prefixed to this precept, “Remember the Sabbath day,” that is, remember to observe that day, as it is explained in Deuteronomy 5:18, because it could more easily pass into oblivion, since it is of positive law, than many other things which are more natural. Yet this positive law, on which this institution rests, is divine law, and with respect to men, altogether immutable.

Spanheim saith: It is to be shown that this precept is not moral according to itself wholly, but in part moral, in part either ceremonial or at least merely positive. For we do not think that it is to be anxiously disputed whether it should be strictly called ceremonial or at least merely positive; it suffices that it is contradistinguished from that which is moral strictly speaking, and therefore immutable.

Maresius saith: As the moral precepts of God are summarily contained in the Decalogue, so they are of natural and perpetual law. For the fourth precept itself concerning the Sabbath is moral as to its substance, although it was ceremonial as to the precise determination of the day, for that some worship, even external and solemn, is due to God, the supreme Lord of all, and to this a certain time, both natural reason dictates, and all nations by their consent approve, but how and when this is to be done depends on His will. By the fourth command, the sanctification of the Sabbath is commanded; in which, although the determination of the day was of positive law, yet the thing commanded, as was said before, is of natural law; indeed, it had not only a spiritual, sacramental, and mystical end, but also a political and natural one, with respect to which even foreigners and proselytes of the gate were bound to its observation among the Israelites. And since by the authority of Christ on the first day of the week, on which He rose, and again eight days after appearing to His disciples, John 20:19,26, and by the example and practice of the Apostles and the Apostolic Church, which met on the first day of the week to break bread, that is, to celebrate the Eucharist, Acts 20:7, and to make collections for the use of the poor, 1 Corinthians 16:2, whence also chiefly from the Lord’s resurrection, this day is called the Lord’s Day, Revelation 1:10, the Sabbath is not indeed entirely abrogated, as the Socinians will, but for various reasons transferred to the Lord’s Day or Sunday, yet with that rigor removed to which the Jews were bound, both by God’s ceremonial law itself and by innate superstition, by which they made rites otherwise difficult enough most difficult for themselves; we also are bound to the sanctification of that day, that, namely, ceasing from labors and external works as much as possible, we may spend it in divine worship both publicly and privately.

Walaeus saith: The National Synod of Dort, when after the departure of the foreign theologians those controversies had already been brought to it, judged that it was not of its forum to decide them fully with the condemnation of the other party; because they pertained also to other Reformed Churches, but judged it more advisable to apply that moderation, that, other disputations being dismissed, it should commend to both parties that opinion in which the deputies from both sides, certain arbiters being constituted, had agreed. Which moderation, that it is most to be approved even today, no one studious of the peace of the Church and of divine truth can doubt. Moreover, the articles in which agreement was then made on both sides, and which therefore were commended by the same Synod to our Churches, as they were conceived and approved in Session 164 of the authentic Acts of the same National Synod (whence we have transcribed them), are the following:

  1. In the fourth precept of the divine law, something is ceremonial, something moral.
  2. Ceremonial was the rest of the seventh day from the creation; the rigid observation of the same day, peculiarly prescribed to the Jewish people.
  3. But moral, that a certain and fixed day be destined for the worship of God, and so much rest as is necessary for the worship of God and holy meditation on Him.
  4. The Sabbath of the Jews being abrogated, the Lord’s Day is solemnly to be sanctified by Christians.
  5. This day has always been observed in the ancient Catholic Church since the Apostles.
  6. The same day is to be consecrated to divine worship, so that in it one ceases from all [works], except those which are of charity or present necessity: and from such recreations as hinder the worship of God.

To which opinions, for the fuller understanding of the mind of the Synod concerning the last article, we shall subjoin the words of the same National Synod, which in Session 177 were inserted in a supplicatory letter to the Mighty States General of these United Provinces against the profanation of the Sabbath. They are in Article 14 thus: “That those most grievous and manifold profanations of the Sabbath, which are done daily through fairs, dedications, feasts of communities, watches, neighborhoods, weddings; through exercises of arms, through huntings, fishings, fowlings, ball games; through histrionic actions of comedies, through dances, auctions of goods, drunkennesses, and through any less necessary servile works, and many other such things, which in these regions, with great scandal and dishonor of the Reformed religion, and with great hindrance to divine worship, are everywhere increasing, may be most strictly prohibited and prevented.”

XXVI. The Fifth Precept

The fifth precept, founded upon the law of mutual charity and justice amongst men one toward another, doth comprehend the duties of inferiors—namely, of children—toward superiors, whether they be parents, lords, or magistrates, with the promise of a life long and good annexed thereto.

Ursinus saith: Now follow the laws of the second table, the obedience whereof verily pertaineth equally unto God as that of the first table, but the works thereof immediately concern men. The sum of them, and the rule for understanding them, Christ Himself hath comprised in this word, “Thou shalt love thy neighbor as thyself” (Matthew 22), and expoundeth it, Matthew 7, “Whatsoever ye would that men should do unto you, so also do ye unto them. This is the law and the prophets”—that is, the same we should perform unto others which, if we were in their place, we would justly will to be performed unto us by them. And since concerning the second table Christ pronounceth, Matthew 22, “The second is like unto the first,” this likeness appeareth in the kind of chief divine worship, which is set before ceremonies; in the kind of eternal punishment, which is inflicted for the violation of either table; and in the coherence of the love of God and of the neighbor as cause and effect, whereby it cometh that neither is performed without the other. The chief causes in God’s sight ought to be considered wherefore God willeth obedience to the second table to be performed—namely, first, that by this obedience also He Himself may be worshipped, and His love, by the love of the neighbor for His sake, may be exercised and declared; second, that through love the conformity of men with God may be shown; third, that the society of men, ordained by God for the celebration of Himself, may be preserved.

Ames saith: Thus far concerning religion; there followeth justice, which is contained in the second table. Justice is the virtue whereby we are inclined unto the performance of due duty unto our neighbor. Thus the duty of children toward their parents is said to be just (Ephesians 6:1), and the duty of lords toward their servants is called right and equal (Colossians 4:1), and all those things which we owe unto our neighbors are performed by living justly (Titus 2:12). Yet in this number and name, by analogy, each one is included also with respect unto himself; for every man is first a neighbor unto himself, then unto others. Whence also it is that no singular precept is given whereby a man is ordered against himself; for while he is rightly ordered toward God and toward his neighbor, at the same time he is ordered toward himself, but with this difference: that disposition whereby one is made fit to perform his duty unto God and his neighbor pertaineth unto his perfection, but the same duties he oweth both unto his neighbor and unto himself (not, however, unto God and himself). And because that manner whereby duties toward the neighbor are to be exercised is with respect and affection unto their good, hence this same virtue is called charity toward the neighbor (Matthew 22:29; Mark 12:31). And among men, those more than others are to be loved who draw nearer unto God and, in God, unto ourselves (Galatians 6:10): “Let us do good unto all, but especially unto the household of faith.” Yet in this prerogative of charity, those goods alone are more to be desired for our conjoined ones which properly pertain unto that conjunction whereby they touch us—spiritual goods for those who spiritually are most conjoined unto us, and goods of nature for those with whom we have a natural conjunction; not that these kinds of goods are in our desires to be separated one from another, but that the kind itself of conjunction is as it were a nod of God, whereby we are stirred by Him to place our work especially in this or that kind. Hence it followeth: kinsmen, other things being equal, are to be loved more than strangers in those things which pertain unto the goods of this life, and among kinsmen, those who are nearer above others. Here is presupposed and sanctioned the society of men among themselves, whether private or economical, and public or political, whereby some must serve others with mutual duties of justice and charity conjoined, that they may exercise and show that religion whereby they worship God toward men. And although political society be sanctioned by God equally as economical, yet not, as of this (together with ecclesiastical), is any certain form thereof prescribed by God unto all peoples, but is left unto their liberty, that (their power remaining whole) they may institute that which most maketh for religion and justice to be established among them. And this is one reason wherefore mention is made only of parents in the fifth precept: because the economical society alone, which is plainly natural through all ages and all nations, was one and the same measure; whereunto this also is added, that this is the first degree wherein is the fountain and seedbed of all society; whence also the authority of all others excelling in superior power is designated and softened by the appellation of “father” (2 Kings 2:12; 5:13; 13:14; Genesis 41:8; 1 Samuel 24:12; 1 Timothy 5:1). Honor is the acknowledgment of dignity or excellence which is in another, with due testimony thereof. Acknowledgment is said at once with testimony, because it consisteth neither in external observance alone nor in internal alone, but in both. It is said to regard excellence or dignity, because we are not moved with reverence save from the apprehension of some preeminence. Hence, both commonly and most properly, that duty is noted by the name of honor and reverence which is due unto those who are placed above us in some eminence; but by synecdoche it designateth every duty whereby respect is had unto the degree of dignity or excellence of another, whether that degree be unequal with respect unto us or equal (Romans 12:10, “In honor preferring one another”; 1 Peter 3:7, “Ye husbands, dwell with them according to knowledge, giving honor unto the wife as unto the weaker vessel”; 1 Peter 2:17, “Honor all men”). And they are either private or public. Private are the husband with respect unto the wife, parents with respect unto children, and masters with respect unto servants—where the marital power is tempered with a certain equality, the masterful is merely commanding, but the paternal is as it were mixed. Those who excel by public authority are either ministers or magistrates.

Calvin saith: But since this precept concerning subjection doth greatly strive with the depravity of human wit (which, as it is swollen with desire of loftiness, hardly endureth to be subjected), that superiority which by nature is most amiable and least invidious is proposed as an example, because it could more easily soften and bend our minds unto the custom of submission. Therefore, unto all lawful subjection, from that which is easiest to bear, the Lord gradually accustometh us, since the reason is the same for all. And from the various appendages of the law it appeareth true that which we have noted: that there be three parts of the honor whereof it here speaketh—reverence, obedience, gratitude. The first the Lord sanctifieth when He commandeth that he be put to death who curseth father or mother, since there He avengeth contempt and reproach. The second, when He decreeth the penalty of death against the disobedient and rebellious. Unto the third pertaineth that which Christ saith, Matthew 15, that it is of the precept of God that we do good unto parents. And as oft as Paul maketh mention of the commandment, he interpreteth that obedience is required therein.

Professor saith: The Anabaptists err, who, numbering the function of the magistrate among things evil and in themselves unlawful, deem that unto it, though it be faithful, a place in the Christian Church must be denied. For the political function, which the whole Scripture of both Testaments ascribeth unto the ordinance of God, is in itself perpetually good, and therefore no less ought to be approved by our churches than by the Apostolic; unto which were admitted Nicodemus (John 3:2), the ruler (John 4:53), Joseph of Arimathea (John 19:38), Cornelius the centurion (Acts 10:34), Sergius Paulus the proconsul (Acts 13:12), and other magistrates believing in Christ, in whom began to be fulfilled that which Isaiah of old foretold concerning the magistrates of the Catholic Christian Church (Isaiah 49:22; 60:2-3): “Over thee shall Jehovah arise, and His glory shall be seen upon thee, that the nations may come unto thy light, and kings unto the brightness of thy rising.” Hence David, moved by the prophetic Spirit, exhorteth them that they kiss the Son of God (Psalm 2:12). Therefore, the Anabaptists and Socinians err, who deny that unto the Christian magistrate also war is divinely lawful, not considering that neither John the Baptist, nor Christ, nor the Apostles, unto the centurions and soldiers seeking counsel of salvation from them and professing the Christian faith, counseled that they cast away their arms, but that they be content with their wages (Matthew 8; Luke 3; Acts 10). Hereunto must be added the example of the Apostle Paul, who, knowing of the conspiracy of certain Jews against him, using the guard and defense of the Roman tribunes against those Jews, by this his deed demonstrated that any magistrate by divine right may use the sword for the protection of the good (Acts 23:21). The same Apostle, appealing unto Caesar and answering Festus that he ought to be judged at his tribunal (Acts 25:10), hinteth that the judgment of the magistrate against evildoers is of divine and common right, and therefore lawful even under the Gospel. For that which repugneth divine and perpetual right he never would have said ought to be done. The same warneth the Romans (Romans 13:4) that the magistrate may by right and merit punish evildoers with the sword. Whereby is overthrown this axiom of the Socinians: that the doctrine of the Gospel permitteth not a Christian that man should take away the life of man—which axiom of theirs can be refuted by the saying of Christ, Matthew 26:52, “He that taketh the sword shall perish by the sword.” For unto the ancient sanction of the divine law Christ appealeth, that He might show it to be of primitive and perpetual right, namely unto that of Genesis 9:6, “Whoso sheddeth man’s blood, by man shall his blood be shed”—to wit, not by private and disordered vengeance, but by public and ordered; which the Socinians, confounding private and disordered vengeance with this, from places where the former is forbidden (namely Matthew 5:39; Romans 12:17, 19), wrongly infer the prohibition of the latter also. The Canonists and other Papists also err, who affirm that ecclesiastics are altogether and simply immune from the yoke of the political magistrate, and think their assertion resteth upon divine right. For the Apostle, regarding divine right, exhorteth every soul that it subject itself unto civil powers and obey them (Romans 13:1). Either, therefore, every Romanist cleric lacketh a rational soul, or, if he be endowed with one, he is comprehended in their number whom the Apostle, writing unto the Romans, by the synecdochical appellation of “every soul” designateth. But surely, the holier and more religious the calling of Christian men be, the more holily and religiously ought the law of God concerning obedience to magistrates to be observed by them, since neither Christ, who was separate from all sin, refused their authority (Matthew 17:27; John 19:11), nor the priests, prophets, and apostles of the ancient Church of God, consecrated by singular reason. I add that the Apostle Peter, whose successor the Roman Pontiff boasteth himself to be, exhorteth all the elect of God unto sanctification of the Spirit—among whom his clerics wish to be numbered—that they subject themselves not only unto the highest but also unto inferior magistrates (1 Peter 2:13).

Ames saith: The precept is called “the first with promise” (Ephesians 6:2), either because it is the first of the second table, or because it is the first and only one in the whole law which hath a singular promise proper unto itself annexed.

Geneva saith: Nor therefore must it be established that this promise is vain, because not always are they long-lived or do they enjoy prosperous things in this life who perform this duty, nor do all violators of this precept die in youth. For with benefits pertaining unto this life the Lord so moderateth as He knoweth expedient; and the obedient unto parents He the more quickly calleth hence, the more quickly He blesseth; but the longer life of the rebellious so commendeth the patience of God, that nevertheless it turneth unto them as a curse.

XXVII. The Sixth Precept

By the sixth precept is forbidden whatsoever unjust harm to the life and body of the neighbor, and also of oneself.

Geneva saith: Since life provideth subsistence unto the human race, and the following precepts pertain directly unto its preservation, deservedly is this precept placed in the first place; the reason whereof is threefold: namely, purely and directly divine, natural, and political.

Ursinus saith: The end of this precept is the preservation of life and the safety of bodies. It commandeth, therefore, zeal for preserving our life and that of another, and forbiddeth all unjust harm thereof, and the desire of such harm, and the signification of this desire. For that which God willeth not to be done by us, that neither doth He permit to be sought or wished; and that whose desire He forbiddeth, the signification thereof by words, countenance, or gesture He also prohibiteth. And He nameth in the prohibition murder, that together with the effect He may take away the proper causes, and, comprehending the coherent sins under the name of murder, by the signification of their gravity He may more effectually deter us from them.

Ames saith: Murder is the unjust slaying of a man. That slaying, and also harm, is unjust which either is not done by just authority—that is, public, or equivalent unto public—or not from a just cause, or not in a just order, or from an intention not just. For these four conditions must always concur unto a just slaying; if one of them be wanting, murder is committed. Unto murder also must be referred rash anger insofar as it tendeth unto the harm of the neighbor (Matthew 5:22, “Whosoever is angry with his brother without a cause”). But from those very words it is given to be observed that not all anger is condemned; for that alone is reproved which is rash—that is, which hath no just cause or observeth not a just measure. Otherwise the impulse of anger, as the zeal of God, is oft praised (Exodus 11:8; 16:20; 32:19; Numbers 16:15; 31:14; 2 Kings 13:19), and hatred itself (Psalm 139:21-22). This is peculiar almost unto the sixth precept, that those things which are forbidden may sometimes (by another reason) be done not ill, and sometimes even rightly and well, out of observance toward God. Thus he who by mere chance, whereunto he gave not cause, while he giveth diligence unto a lawful thing, where and when it is lawful, with due care employed, slayeth another, sinneth not (Deuteronomy 19:5). Such also is the reason of necessary defense, so long as the desire of revenge be absent. For this is the blameless protection granted unto each.

Musculus saith: Hither also are to be referred those who slay themselves. For no one hath received power over his own life thus far, that it be lawful for him to take it away when he willeth not, and to be judge of himself. This happeneth most often from impatience or fear, whereby some danger is dreaded which is thought to be about to be inflicted; or from some heavier grief, whereby a mind weaker than is meet is oppressed; or from despair of salvation, as it befell Judas the betrayer.

Ursinus saith: Just war is approved in the fifth precept, as part of the magistrate’s duty toward subjects, and in this precept, as the defense of the safety and life of oneself and of another, and consisteth partly in justice not harming and punishing, partly in fortitude and retribution. For it is either a necessary defense against those exercising robbery or cruelty upon subjects, or a just punishment for atrocious injuries, which is undertaken by ordinary power with armed hand (1 Samuel 15, “The battles of Jehovah my Lord hath fought”). Hereunto pertaineth the defense of one’s own life or of neighbors against unjust force, done by private persons, when necessity suffereth not the aid of the magistrate to be implored. For when laws and magistrates then arm a private man against a robber or ravisher—not rashly seized, but justly delivered into his hand by the magistrate with the sword—he useth it as a minister of the magistrates. Thus Moses slew the Egyptian, defending an Israelite.

Ames saith: War can never be just on both parts, because the cause of death cannot be on both sides. Nor in that war is it lawful to intend the slaying of those who are in no wise partakers of such cause. But if there be a legitimate cause, together with just authority, and the intention and manner employed be just, war itself, or soldiery, fighteth not against religion, justice, or charity (Numbers 31:3; 1 Samuel 18:16; 25:28; 1 Chronicles 5:22; Luke 3:14; Romans 13:4; 1 Peter 2:14). Under the same conditions observed, it is lawful for those who know how to use arms to offer and devote their service unto lawful leaders for the waging of war (1 Chronicles 5:18; Psalm 143:1; Luke 3:14; 1 Corinthians 9:7). That anyone should slay himself, no law of God permitteth. Yet it is lawful and just sometimes that one expose himself unto certain peril of death. Yea, there is given sometimes a case wherein one both can and ought to offer himself unto death (John 15:13).

XXVIII. The Seventh Precept

The seventh precept, with adultery, condemneth all lust and carnal impurity.

Geneva saith: By this precept, synecdochically, all conjunction of male and female outside marriage is forbidden, and also all incitements of lust. And of unlawful conjunction there be five kinds: incest, fornication, rape, adultery, and lust contrary to nature. Incest is the conjunction of kinsfolk or affines, which in degree or series of generations is forbidden both by the law of honesty itself, commonly called public, and by the law divinely promulgated, concerning which degrees it is lawful for no mortal to remit. Therefore the Pope is condemned, who attributeth unto himself power to remit concerning those degrees at his pleasure. Nor doth it in any wise favor him that in the first times men took even their own sisters. For this they did under the compulsion of necessity, the human race not yet being multiplied; which, since God willed it to be propagated from one male and one female, at the same time it is necessarily understood that He appointed the conjunction of brothers and sisters then. This cause ceasing, therefore, it is clear that it is not to be held for common right. Fornication is conjunction with a harlot, which by the same reason is condemned by the law of God as other conjunctions outside marriage. For in their own body men sin by all unlawful conjunctions and violate the temple of the Holy Spirit. And so most grievously are they to be condemned who deem that brothels ought to be permitted for the avoiding of greater peril. Rape is committed when any unmarried person outside marriage hath dealings with a virgin or widow. Adultery is when the conjugal bed (which ought to be of one man with one woman) is violated by husband or wife. Polygamy, therefore, though long tolerated among the ancient fathers, yet never according to conscience, or before God, was lawful. Nor hath God ever approved divorces (save for the cause of adultery). And if any add force unto such forbidden concubinages, that he sinneth more gravely is without doubt. Lust contrary to nature is when, with beastly fury and nature itself execrating the crime, either males with males or females with females burn, or even with brutes by abominable wickedness pollute themselves. This precept pertaineth unto all ages, sexes, and conditions of men. God, who alone is the knower of hearts and abominateth all contamination (in whatsoever part of soul or body it appear), by this precept forbiddeth unto us not only these external crimes but also the internal and those things which are provocative unto lust. He prohibiteth, therefore, chiefly that the mind within burn not with lust; and so that in the eyes, hands, or any habit or state of the body there be not aught that savoreth of unchastity and lasciviousness; finally, all filthy speech, all lascivious writings, and shameful pictures are forbidden by God.

Ames saith: Unto luxury are numbered all its helping causes, effects, and signs: as unchaste looks (Job 31:1; Proverbs 9:13; 2 Peter 2:14; Matthew 5:28), nods, kisses, embraces, touches, dances, spectacles, songs, gestures, and the like (Galatians 5:19). Unto the helping causes of luxury are referred revellings and drunkennesses (Romans 13:13; Ezekiel 16:49; Proverbs 23:31, 33). Unto its effects and signs is referred lascivious luxury and adornment (Proverbs 7:11) and obscenity of words (Ephesians 5:4).

Bucanus saith: A question ariseth: Whether it be lawful for ministers of the church to enter into marriage?

Answer: It is lawful:

I. Because God hath made them also fit for marriage and the procreation of children, and the conjunction of male and female is of the right of nature (Genesis 1:27; 2:18).

II. Because it is holy, good, and honorable among all in all things, and the bed undefiled (Hebrews 13:4). For Christ calleth marriage a divine conjunction, therefore holy, when He saith, Matthew 19:6, “What God hath joined together.” And Paul (1 Timothy 4:4-5) saith that marriage, meats, and the like are sanctified by the word and prayer. Likewise that an unbelieving husband is sanctified in a believing wife (1 Corinthians 7:14). Likewise that a woman is saved through the bearing of children, for the sake of faith (1 Timothy 2:15). And finally, “All things are clean unto the clean,” who are justified by faith (Titus 1:15). And Paphnutius said in the Nicene Synod that chastity is cohabitation with one’s own wife (Sozomen, Book 1, Chapter 23).

III. Because the Apostle of the Gentiles saith that a bishop must be blameless and the husband of one wife (1 Timothy 3:2; Titus 1:6)—not of one church, as the Papists will, because in that place the Apostle hath discourse not of the office of a bishop but of the quality of the bishop’s person. Nor doth he forbid that, the first being dead, he take another; for he also who taketh a second wife, the first being dead, is the husband of one wife if he be content with his spouse, but he willeth an honest husband to be content with one spouse, nor, after the manner of the Jews and Gentiles, to have two or more wives at the same time.

IV. Because the ministers of the Gospel sustain the person of the Levitical priests, who yet not perpetually, but only when they approached the holy things, abstained from the use of marriage. For they were antitypes of Christ the Mediator, whose more-than-angelic purity, beyond human custom, they ought in some wise to represent. But also, when about to enter the tabernacle, they abstained from wine (Leviticus 10:9), and from the funerals of the dead (Leviticus 21:1), and from shaving (ibid., v. 5), wherein yet the Papist priests imitate them not. Yet the godly know to moderate the use of marriage according to the time. They know this also, that Paul commandeth to possess their vessels in sanctification (1 Thessalonians 4:4), and that sometimes they must withdraw, that they may give themselves unto prayer, which yet Paul willeth not to be perpetual (1 Corinthians 7:5).

V. By inversion, because priests, prophets, prophetesses, apostles (as Peter and others, of whom 1 Corinthians 9:5), and apostolic men (for Polycrates, Bishop of the Ephesians, saith that he was the eighth bishop, born of former bishops, in Eusebius, Ecclesiastical History, Book 5) had spouses.

VI. Because Daniel 11:37 attributeth this mark unto Antichrist, that he shall rule in the church, nor care for women, but shall defile the church with foul and incestuous lusts. And Paul (1 Timothy 4:1) expressly calleth the law of celibacy in general a doctrine of demons.

VII. Because Christ saith, Matthew 15:9, “In vain do they worship me with commandments of men,” and 19:12, willeth all to use marriage, save those whom either nature hath created unfit for marriage, or chance hath rendered impotent, or singular grace hath made continent, that they may live purely even without a spouse. Concerning all others the saying of Christ holdeth, verse 11, “Not all men receive this word, but they to whom it is given,” and 1 Corinthians 7:7, “Every man hath his proper gift, one after this manner, another after that,” and 1 Corinthians 12:4.

VIII. Because that Papist celibacy laboreth under that public infamy of shameful and prodigious lusts, which burn among those fathers who feign themselves Curii and live Bacchanalia.

XXIX. The Eighth Precept

The eighth precept forbiddeth theft and the kinds and manners thereof.

Geneva saith: By the two superior precepts provision was made for the preservation of human society as touching the persons themselves; but in this the Lord prescribeth the protection of goods, that it may serve both individual families and the common utility.

Calvin saith: The end thereof, since injustice is an abomination unto God, is that unto each be rendered that which is his own. The sum, therefore, shall be that we are forbidden to covet the things of others, and therefore are commanded to bestow faithful labor in preserving unto each his goods. For thus it must be thought: that unto each hath befallen what he possesseth not by fortuitous chance, but from the distribution of the supreme Lord of all things; therefore the faculties of any cannot be perverted by evil arts without fraud being done unto the divine dispensation.

Ames saith: Justice which regardeth the external commodities of the neighbor by a certain appropriation is called commutative justice, because it is chiefly employed in exchanges. This justice is the virtue whereby unto each is given his own in external commodities. And that is called each one’s own whereof he hath lawful dominion. Dominion is the right of disposing perfectly of a thing, so far as the laws permit (Matthew 20:15). Of perfect dominion there be two parts: property and usufruct (Luke 20:9-10; 1 Corinthians 9:7). And these sometimes are separated, so that property is with one, and usufruct for a time is with another. This justice is exercised in acquisition and in use. The justice of acquisition dependeth upon the cause of dominion. The cause and reason of dominion is called title. A just title is just occupation, inheritance, gift, wages, or contract. Theft is the unjust taking away of another’s thing, the owner being unwilling (Ephesians 4:28). Taking away comprehendeth acceptance, detention, and damage. A thing is called another’s which is of another, either as to property, power, or possession.

Geneva saith: By the name of theft this precept synecdochically comprehendeth every kind of injury which is inflicted upon the goods of the neighbor—to wit, both the occupation and the unjust detention of another’s thing, whether it be done by fraud or by open force. This commandment, therefore, wholly repugneth the confusion of goods which certain fanatics, and in this matter not at all divine Plato, and namely in our times the Anabaptists among Christians, strive to establish. Those things which are in the nature of things are either sacred or divine, or human. Sacrilege is the theft of those things which are called divine—not that God needeth these, but from the use and end for which they are destined, to wit, for the worship of God. Human things are either proper or common by right of usufruct and dominion, or another’s. Again, another’s things are either public or private. Peculation is the theft of a public thing, when one diverteth unto his own use and commodity that which belongeth unto the whole commonwealth, whereunto is annexed the crime of extortion. The definition of theft delivered by jurisconsults pertaineth properly unto private things, and is rightly defined as the fraudulent handling of another’s thing for the sake of gain, or of its use or possession, which is forbidden by natural law to be admitted; certain species whereof have their proper appellation, as plagiarism and cattle-theft, but the rest are comprehended under the general name of theft. Theft in general is condemned, whether it concern the substance itself of the thing, or its quality, quantity, and commodity. Guilty of theft, therefore, is not only he who either stealeth or possesseth in bad faith another’s thing, or receiveth it unto himself, but also he who substituteth old for new, who useth false weight and measure, who in bad faith restoreth not another’s thing which he oweth at the time and place appointed. By this precept all are forbidden to steal, of whatsoever age, sex, and condition they be. The appellation of theft in this precept comprehendeth also all evil arts whereby we attempt to make another’s things ours, and which avarice, the root of all such evils, dictateth. Usury—that is, gain—is chiefly to be condemned which anyone either stipulateth or, without stipulation, receiveth from the neighbor’s disadvantage.

Professor saith: Under almsgiving is comprehended the giving of a loan, which is bestowed upon the needy who are not wholly and only for a time in want, unto whom by a loan given counsel must be taken, and that without usury, according to that, Deuteronomy 15:8, “Thou shalt open thy hand unto the poor and give a loan wherein thou seest him to lack,” and of the Psalmist, “The just man hath pity and lendeth” (Psalm 37:26). Which Christ repeateth, “Give to him that asketh of thee, and from him that would borrow of thee turn not away” (Matthew 5:42), and Luke 6:35, “Lend, hoping for nothing again”—that is, beyond the principal, nor even the equal, as appeareth from verse 34; yea, if the matter so require, not even the principal itself, to wit, with a pure mind of doing good; in which sense, according to a certain excess of speech, it is taken comparatively, as other things in the same place. Yet it is lawful to lend unto the needy under the condition of a pledge for the certainty of the principal (Exodus 22:25-26; Deuteronomy 24:10), but with usury and increase it is not lawful. And the usury which in the sacred Scriptures is forbidden is this alone which is exercised with the poor. Whence also the Hebrews by the name “neshekh,” from biting and reason, have it, and mention thereof is almost made when it treateth of the needy and oppressed (Exodus 22:25; Leviticus 25:35-37; Proverbs 22:7). But usury which is exercised with those of moderate fortune or the richer, reduced unto the laws of charity and equity, is a species of lawful contract and hath the reason of interest. Whence truly that usury which is exercised with the poor under the condition of a pledge, and in Christendom by the magistrate in some places, though with respect unto some good, is permitted, is cruel and monstrous, both by the usury itself and by its immensity, whereunto in a well-constituted commonwealth there ought to be no place for any. Much less that unto the Jews, for the reproach and oppression of Christians, usury against them be permitted unpunished (Deuteronomy 23:19-20; 28:13, 44). But contrariwise, as counsel must be taken for the poor by public alms, so also for the want of certain by the altar of charity (as they call it), instituted under a bare pledge by public authority and administration, provision must be made. Nor ought anything further to be taken than what the money taken for that use beareth, if otherwise it cannot be done from the public, and the reckoning of expenses. So far is it that it be lawful to make gain thence.

Musculus saith: Bishops and the rest of the prelates with clerics and monks, without any infamy, commit sacrilege when they transfer ecclesiastical goods unto profane uses. The goods of the church pertain unto the feeding of the poor, the sustaining of ministers, and the repairing of sacred buildings. But they, while neither duly ministering unto the church, nor feeding the poor, nor repairing ecclesiastical buildings, shamefully expend the goods of the church upon their own delights, harlots, and huntings, are surely sacrilegious, and defraud the church of Christ of necessary ministry, the poor of subsidy, and sacred buildings of repair. Yet there is none who punisheth them as sacrilegious, but they are held almost as sacred men and prelates of the church unto whom the goods of the church pertain. Thus in the matter of religion the church is circumvented, not understanding the fraud of its prelates. Then also they commit sacrilege who take away ecclesiastical goods from prelates and clerics and convert them unto their own private uses; which certain princes of old did, and today would that many who yet greatly glory in the Gospel of Christ did not do. In this they sin not, that they keep drones, an idle herd, yea wolves, from the folds; but in this they commit sacrilege, that even as pseudo-bishops they transfer the goods of the church unto private uses and despoil the churches.

XXX. The Ninth Precept

The ninth precept condemneth all falsehood against the neighbor in speaking and in witnessing.

Calvin saith: The end thereof, since God (who is truth) execrateth a lie, is that truth without deceit must be cherished among us. The sum, therefore, shall be that neither by calumnies and false accusations we violate anyone’s name, nor by a lie burden him in his fortunes; finally, that we harm not any by the lust of evil-speaking and impudence. Whereunto is joined the command that, as far as is lawful, we lend faithful labor unto each in asserting the truth, for the safeguarding both of his name and of his goods’ integrity.

Ames saith: A lie properly is a testimony whereby one pronounceth otherwise than he feeleth in his heart (Acts 5:3). Whence that phrase of Scripture concerning the double heart of a lying man (Psalm 12:3). The intention of asserting falsehood constituteth a lie, although that which is said be most true. Among lies, those are graver wherein the testimony is more solemn, as in forensic judgments, which are chiefly regarded in the words of the ninth precept; in sacred things, and the like (Matthew 26:59; 1 Corinthians 15:15). The words of testimony ought always to be employed in that sense wherein they are understood, or are thought to be understood, by those unto whom the witness seeketh to give faith, without equivocation, ambiguity, or any mental reservation. Truth in testimony is threefold: I. When that which is said conformeth unto the thing itself whereof it treateth. II. When it conformeth unto the mind of the speaker. III. When it conformeth both unto the mind and unto the thing. The second truth is that which most properly is regarded in testimony and truth; yet the third is required in those things whereof we either are bound to have certain knowledge or profess it. This veracity is either in simple assertion or in promise.

XXXI. The Tenth Precept

Finally, by the tenth precept God forbiddeth whatsoever evil concupiscence and the first inordinate motions tending unto the disadvantages of the neighbor.

Calvin saith: The end is that, since God willeth the whole soul to be possessed with the affection of love, every desire adverse unto charity must be cast out from our minds. The sum, therefore, shall be that no thought creep unto us which, by concupiscence noxious and tending unto another’s detriment, stir our minds. Whereunto correspondeth on the contrary the precept that whatsoever we conceive, deliberate, will, meditate, it be conjoined with the good and commodity of our neighbors. But here a great and, as it seemeth, perplexing difficulty meeteth us. For if truly it was said by us above that under the names of fornication and theft the lust of fornicating and the counsel of harming and deceiving are restrained, it might seem to have been superfluous that afterward separately the concupiscence of others’ goods should be forbidden unto us. But the distinction between counsel and concupiscence shall easily untie this knot for us. For counsel, as we spake thereof in the superior precepts, is the deliberate consent of the will, where lust hath subdued the mind. Concupiscence can be without such deliberation and consent, when the mind is pricked and tickled only by vain and perverse objects. As, therefore, the Lord hath hitherto commanded the rule of charity to govern wills, endeavors, works, so now He commandeth the conceptions of the mind to be directed unto the same, that there be none perverse and distorted which stir the mind otherwise. As He forbade the mind to be bent and led unto anger, hatred, fornication, rapine, lying, so now He prohibiteth it to be instigated thereto.

Geneva saith: The ninth precept being explained, it remaineth that the tenth be examined, whereby the Lord hath established a law not only for the external acts of the body but also for the internal thoughts of the mind. This precept is set last, because in teaching the best method is to proceed from the known unto the less known; and those things which are placed in certain and constituted deliberation of the will, or in external deeds, are more known than internal lusts, which very few think to be sins so long as they break not forth into act; and none, witness Paul, number them among sins unless consent hath acceded, save those who are admonished by this precept.

Musculus saith: Here must be discerned between the judgment of this world and the judgment of God. No law of the world either forbiddeth or punisheth the concupiscence of the heart.
