Before the world he is sufficiently pure who, abstaining from the endeavor and attempt of an unclean work, can restrain evil in the heart lest by any means it break forth. For a human judge cannot penetrate unto the affections of the heart, which are subject not unto human judgment but unto God’s alone. “No man knoweth,” saith the Apostle, “what is in man.” And in the German proverb we say: “Thoughts are toll-free.” But before the tribunal of the supreme Judge, man is judged not only according to those things which he doeth, but rather according to that which he is. And man is more truly that which he is in heart than that which he showeth in work. The quality of the heart is the quality of the man before God. A heart unclean and adulterous, the man is unclean and an adulterer, if thou regard the judgment of God. Where the uncleanness of the heart breaketh forth outward, it rendereth the man unclean even before men and subject unto human judgment. By this consideration we all are admonished that we think of ourselves not according to the reckonings of human judgment, but according to the infallible censure of God.

Ames saith: By concupiscence, however, is not understood the power and faculty of desiring and appetizing, which is natural; nor the natural act or operation of that faculty, which also is natural and lawful; nor the whole inclination of our nature, which is corrupt, which is not singularly condemned by any one precept but by the whole law; nor all those actual first lusts which are inordinate, a great part whereof are adverse unto religion and condemned by the first table; nor finally all lusts which tend unto the detriment of the neighbor, for those which have deliberate consent and a purpose of pursuing annexed are condemned in the singular precepts; but that concupiscence whereby the mind is first instigated and tickled with the desire of goods which are the neighbor’s, although it hath not yet brought into the mind to acquire the same by unlawful means (1 Kings 21:2; Mark 10:12). The Apostle, Romans 7, openly explaineth this precept by synecdoche concerning the operations of sin; for concupiscence (verse 7) is the same as the affections of sins (verse 5) and as concupiscence effected by sin (verse 8), and so must necessarily be distinguished from sin indwelling (verse 7). Nor is there aught strange in this, that the Pharisees (of whom Paul was one) acknowledged not the first motions of concupiscence to be sins, since the same is yet denied by their kinsmen the Papists, who dissever this last precept concerning concupiscence into two, that one be of the concupiscence of the house and the other of the wife with the following. They in this matter: I. Are forsaken by all reason. II. Are compelled either wholly to erase the second precept of the first table or at least to convert it into a superfluous appendage of the first, that they may seem in some wise to retain the number of ten words—or rather (as is plain in many of them) that, obscuring the force of the second precept, they may with some show remove it from themselves and their superstitions; they are compelled to tear this tenth. III. Whether the ninth or the tenth be the precept they cannot certainly designate, because in the repetition of the law (Deuteronomy 5:27) the concupiscence of the wife is set before the concupiscence of the house. IV. No distinct injustice between these concupiscences can they indicate, whence also it cometh that they themselves in the explication of the Decalogue always conjoin, or rather confound, the ninth and the tenth. V. The very words of the Decalogue expressly note one precept, since they forbid one act, “Thou shalt not covet,” and one common object, “whatsoever is thy neighbor’s.” Unto concupiscence is referred as a cause the inordinate love of ourselves, which is self-love (2 Timothy 3:2). This self-love is in some wise the fountain and origin of all sins, not only against the neighbor but also against God Himself (2 Timothy 3:4). This concupiscence is that which by John is distributed into that which is of the flesh, regarding those things which pertain unto sustenance and lust; and into that which is of the eyes, regarding those things which pertain unto external delight and utility; and into that which is of the pride of life, regarding those things which pertain unto the glory and pomp of this world (1 John 2:16). Contentment is the virtue whereby the mind resteth content in the lot granted by God (1 Timothy 6:6; Hebrews 13:5; Philippians 4:11). This contentment is commanded in the tenth commandment, as appeareth from the words themselves; nor is it in any wise consonant that this commandment be immediately referred unto that purity of internal and original justice which is the fountain of all obedience; for that is not generally commanded in any one mandate, but in all, nor pertaineth more unto the second table, which is the condition of this precept, than unto the first.

XXXII. The Law Cannot Be Perfectly Fulfilled in This Life

The law, thus far explained, cannot by man in this life be perfectly fulfilled.

Ames saith: From that perfection which shineth forth even in any one of these precepts it is manifest that the whole and exact fulfillment of the law is impossible even unto the faithful, out of that measure of grace which they have communicated in this life. For since (that it be not cursed) the rule and measure of obedience in the affirmatives is “Thou shalt love with the whole heart,” and in the negatives “Thou shalt not covet”—both of which in this life are unto us impossible—it followeth necessarily that none can accurately satisfy the law of God. Yet truly and rightly it is said that the yoke of Christ is easy and His burden light (Matthew 11:30), and His commandments are not grievous (1 John 5:3), because the law is considered there: I. As it is observed by the faithful, who delight therein (Romans 7:22; Psalm 119:14), not as it ought to be observed; for that observance bringeth rest unto the souls of the faithful (Matthew 11:29), although the adhering imperfection be unto them grievous and troublesome. II. With respect unto the spirit, not with respect unto the flesh (Matthew 26:41). III. With the remission of sin and all imperfection which adhereth unto our endeavors annexed. IV. In comparison of the letter of the law that killeth. V. With the comparison also of the reward appointed by God unto imperfect begun obedience employed; in which sense all afflictions also are called light (2 Corinthians 4:17). The easiness, therefore, and lightness of the law of God is not in its proportion unto our strength, but in the grace of our Lord Jesus Christ, and the charity of God, together with the communication of the Holy Spirit, which is with all who love the law of God.

Walaeus saith: Objection: But David, Psalm 119:10, saith that he sought the Lord with his whole heart. So also 1 Kings 14:8. Thus saith Hezekiah, Isaiah 38:3, “In truth and in a pure heart I have walked before thee.” Of Zacharias and Elisabeth it is said that they walked in all the justifications and commandments of the Lord blameless (Luke 1:6). Response: Here it treateth of sincerity and endeavor to conform oneself according unto all the divine mandates against hypocrisy. For David prayeth God that God enter not into judgment with him (Psalm 143:2). Hezekiah, verse 17 of the same chapter, saith that God hath cast all his sins behind His back. Zacharias straightway after sinned by unbelief, and was a priest; and therefore for his own sins and those of others he was compelled to sacrifice.

XXXIII. Of Spiritual Warfare

And hence ariseth spiritual warfare in all the regenerate with sin.

Ames saith: Since this sanctification is imperfect while we live here as infants, therefore all the faithful are informed as it were with a double form, sin and grace; for the perfection of sanctification in this life is found not save in the dreams of certain fanatics (1 John 1:8, “If we say that we have no sin, we deceive ourselves”). Yet unto perfection all truly sanctified strive (Matthew 5:48; 1 Corinthians 13:11; 2 Peter 3:18). The sin which remaineth in the sanctified, or the corrupt part, is called in the Scriptures the old man, the outward man, the members and body of sin. Grace, or the renewed part, is called the new man, the Spirit, the mind. Hence two things follow: I. A spiritual war which between these parts is perpetually waged (Galatians 5:16-17). II. The daily renewal of repentance. That flesh which remaineth in the regenerate is not only in the vegetative and sensitive appetite, but also in the will and reason itself (1 Thessalonians 5:23). This flesh or concupiscence hath the true and proper reason of sin in the regenerate themselves. By this flesh even the best works of the saints are infected, so that they have need of some remission. Yet the good works of the regenerate are not to be called sins, but infected with sin. This infection of good works (by reason of justification) effecteth not that they be not accepted unto reward by God. That strife which is found in the unrighteous between conscience and will is not the struggle of the spirit against the flesh, but of the flesh fearing against the flesh coveting.

XXXIV. Of the Perseverance of the Saints

Nevertheless, those whom God hath truly sanctified and delivered unto Christ never wholly fall away from Him.

Spanheim saith: The foundations and principles of this perseverance of the saints can be considered, both internal and external. The chief external are: I. The immutability of the divine decree. II. The efficacy of the merit and intercession of Christ. III. The custody of God. IV. The promises annexed unto the covenant of grace. The internal are both the nature of spiritual life and the firmness of the union of the faithful with Christ, and the efficacious supply of strengthening grace.

The external are:

I. The decree of election, which is firm (2 Timothy 2:19), abiding (Romans 9:11), immutable (Hebrews 6:17), and efficacious both by reason of the end and by reason of the means conjoined with the end by an individual nexus (Romans 8:29-30). Nor truly can an immanent act of God either be rescinded or changed—neither by the Creator, seeing He is always consistent with Himself, and with whom is neither change nor shadow of turning (James 1:17), nor by the creature, seeing it hath neither power nor potency against the Creator or into the acts of the Creator. Add that neither can an act of God be changed for the better, seeing it is always best, nor for the worse, lest God cease to be what He is.

II. The merit and efficacy of the Redeemer, who neither acquired an evanescent benefit for His own by atonement on earth, nor applieth it changeably by manifestation in heaven (John 6:35, 37, 39; Romans 8:33).

III. The power of the Custodian, who both keepeth His own and upholdeth their hand (Psalm 37:24), nor suffereth His sheep to be snatched from His hand, and maketh that they perish not forever (John 10:28-29), and so either averteth temptations, or overthroweth them, or turneth them unto good, nor suffereth His own to be tempted above that which they are able, yea granteth with the temptation also the issue, that they may be able to bear it (1 Corinthians 10:13). Whence the sons of God are more than conquerors (Romans 8:37), because He that is in them is greater than he that is in the world (1 John 4:4).

From those external principles flow the internal principles of perseverance:

II. The union of the faithful with Christ, which both intensively is of the highest vigor and extensively of perpetual duration. Of the highest vigor, because he that is joined unto Christ is made one spirit with Him (1 Corinthians 6:17), and hath from Him not only the influx of regenerating grace but also the influx of strengthening and preserving grace (Philippians 1:6). Of perpetual duration also is that union, because with respect unto all differences of times it hath provided for those who through true faith are grafted in: as to the past time, they are said already to have passed from death unto life; as to the present, they are said to have eternal life; as to the future, they are said not to come into condemnation, nor to be cast out (John 5:24).

From this union of the faithful with Christ floweth: II. Spiritual life, which, unlike animal life, is not subject unto perishing or extinction, because its principle and bond is immovable, and is called a seed abiding (1 John 3:9), an anointing abiding (1 John 2:27), an immortal seed (1 Peter 1:23), a fountain of water springing up into eternal life (John 4:14). But as animal life suffereth its faintings, nor is its course and vigor always the same, but sometimes languor, stupor, insensibility, lethargy, acute diseases, whereby all supply and breath of life seem as it were to be cut off, yet by no means is it wholly cut off—so also spiritual life in the grievous lapses of the saints hath its faintings, languisheth sometimes, and seemeth to be choked, yet by no means is it wholly choked or extinguished, but through subsequent acts of repentance and faith is restored, as oft as the sinner struggleth forth, and from that very fall, as with spirit gathered, is inflamed with graver hatred of evil and more ardent love of good.
